column5: おや、どうしたんです？
column6: Oh, what's the matter?

column5:
え‥いえ、よ、用なんてない
んです‥お、おジャマしました！
column6: Er...No, I-I don't really need anything...Excuse me!

column5:
？？\n
はぁ‥それでは、失礼します。
column6:
??\n
(sigh)...Well, goodbye.

column5: 渡し船がないわね。
column6: The ferry's not here.

column5: 大島に戻ったんでしょう。
column6: It must have gone back to Ohshima.

column5:
６時頃に着く渡し船が、今日
の最終便だって、船頭さんが言って
たのを聞きました。
column6: I heard the ferryman saying the boat that arrived at 6:00 was the last ride for today.

column5:
へぇ？\n
そんな事、言ってたっけ？
column6:
Hm?\n
Did he say something like that?

column5:
エヘン。\n
ナビは、耳も高性能なんです。
column6:
Eh-hem.\n
Navi's ears are high-performance, too.

column5:
へぇ、こんな所に浜辺があっ
たんだ。
column6: Ooh...So there's a beach somewhere like this.

column5:
周囲が岩場に囲まれてますか
ら、ちょっと見ただけでは分かりま
せんね。
column6: The surrounding area is enclosed by rocks, so you wouldn't know it at a glance.

column5:
この岩場の向こうが、港だよ
ね？
column6: So the harbor's on the other side of these rocks?

column5:
そうですよ。\n
‥とは言っても、この険しい岩場の
５００メートル先ですけどね。
column6:
That's right.\n
...Though it's 500 meters away over steep rock.

column5:
ロープですか？\n
海から流れ着いたんでしょうか。
column6:
Is that a rope?\n
Maybe it washed in from the sea.

column5:
ロープの端が岩場に結び付け
られてるからね。\n
誰かが結んだのは間違いないよ。
column6: The rope's end is attached to the rocks. Someone definitely tied it there.

column5:
ま、たいして意味はないだろ
うけどね。
column6: Oh well, I doubt there's really any significance to it.

column5:
天狗岩（てんぐいわ）\n
花コウ岩でできた巨岩塔。
column6:
Tengu Rock\n
An enormous rock tower made of granite.

column5:
海上からの高さは、１１．４ｍにも
達します。
column6: It extends 11.4 meters above sea level.

column5:
その昔、児島の天狗と大島の天狗が
力を競い合った時に、児島天狗が投
げた岩であると伝えられています。
岬の先端から、眺めることができま
す。
column6:
Legend tells that in ancient times, when the tengu of Kojima had a contest of might with the tengu of Ohshima, the Kojima tengu threw this rock.
[wait][clear]

You can look out upon it from the tip of the cape.
column7: NOTE: no voice acting, so this is a rare occasion where we can add extra boxes of text without issue

column5: ‥こっちは裏ですって。
column6: ...Hey, this is the back.

column5:
‥なによ。寒いだけの、ただ
の洞窟じゃない。
column6: ...What's the big deal? It's just some dank cave.

column5: ロープが張ってありますね。
column6: A rope's been hung here.

column5:
順路から外れるんでしょ。\n
[expr]<$01>迷わないように、そうしてあるんだ
よ。
column6: That goes off the main route, right? [expr]<$01>They've done it to keep people from wandering.

column5:
この先には行けないみたいだ
ね。
column6: It looks like we can't go this way.

column5: 奥は、どうなってた？
column6: What's the inner part like?

column5:
は？\n
ナビに見えるはず、ないですよ。
column6:
Huh?\n
Navi wouldn't be able to see that.

column5:
この身体はただの立体映像で
ナビの目は、メイの右手にある本体
に付いてるんですから。
column6: This body is just a projection. Navi's eyes are in the main unit on your right hand.
column7: NOTE: you might think there's some significance to this and it'll come up later in the plot. you'd be wrong.

column5:
‥‥そうだった。\n
たまに忘れるんだよね。
column6:
...That's right.\n
Sometimes I forget.

column5:
これが夜光ゴケ‥。\n
普通のコケに見えるけどなぁ。
column6:
This is noctilucent moss...\n
It looks like regular moss, though.

column5:
これが夜光ゴケ‥。\n
へぇ、きれいに光るもんだねぇ‥。
column6:
This is noctilucent moss...\n
Ooh, it shines so prettily...

column5: これが照明のスイッチだね。
column6: This is the light switch.

column5:
へぇぇ‥これは、\n
[2x]\s<$01>すごいじゃない！
column6:
Oooh...[br3]
This is [2x]\s<$01>awesome![1x]

column5: ほんと‥‥きれいだねぇ。
column6: It really is...So pretty.

column5:
ちょ、ちょっとメイ!!\n
何やってんのよっ！
column6:
H-hey, May!\n
What're you doing!?

column5: いたたたたぁ‥。
column6: Ouuuuuch...

column5:
はぁ‥、かんなもあんたも、
ほんっとに世話やかせるんだから‥
column6: (sigh)...You and Kanna both, just the most helpless people in the world...

column5:
ほら、夜光ゴケが服について
るじゃない。
column6: Look, you've got noctilucent moss stuck to your clothes.

column5:
メイ！\n
照明をつけてませんよ。
column6:
May!\n
The lights aren't on.

column5:
夜光洞（やこうどう）\n
夜光ゴケが自生する洞窟です。
column6:
Noctilucent Cave\n
A cave where noctilucent moss grows natively.

column5:
夜光ゴケはセン類に属するコケ植物
であり、発光する性質を持っている
珍しい植物です。
column6: Noctilucent moss is a bryophyte with the unusual property of emitting light.
column7: NOTE: if you take this literally it's "noctilucent moss is a moss belonging to the mosses", which doesn't exactly work in english

column5:
発光のために微量元素を必要とする
ため、自生域は限られています。
column6: Because it requires micronutrients for the emission of light, its native range is limited.

column5:
夜光洞では、洞窟の奥に備えられた
スイッチで照明を消すことができま
す。
column6: In Noctilucent Cave, you can turn off the lights using the switch installed within the cave.

column5:
夜光ゴケと岩石に含まれる鉱物が闇
に放つ光が、幻想的な世界をつくり
あげます。
column6: The light given off by the noctilucent moss and the minerals in the rocks creates a fantastic world.

column5:
←照明用スイッチ\n
消した後は、必ずつけるようにして
ください。
column6:
[<-] Light Switch\n
After turning off, please be sure to turn back on.

column5:
ん〜とね‥児島にあるホテル
に部屋をとってあるから‥。\n
ここから、渡し船に乗るのよね。
column6: Hmm, let's see...I booked rooms at the hotel on Kojima, so...we'll be taking the ferry from here.

column5:
ほら。\n
あそこに見えるじゃない。
column6: Look, see it over there?

column5:
お客さん、ダメですよ。\n
ここは立入禁止なんですから‥。
column6:
Sorry, ma'am.\n
This area's off-limits.

column5:
ヘ、ヘビに話しかけてるんで
すか？
column6: I-is she talking to the snakes?

column5:
今は棚の上に置いてあるぞ。
お婆さんが来たら、返すつもりじゃ
がの。
column6:
I've put it on the shelf for now.\n
I'm planning to give it back to the old woman if she drops by.

column5:
私達の部屋は５０１号室です
から、よろしければ本当に誘って下
さいね。
column6: We're in Room 501, so if you'd like to, really[nbsp]-- ask us.

column5: 順を追って説明しますね。
column6: I'll explain in order.

column5:
１：書き込む\c<$0C>地名\c<$0F>を指すように、\c<$0B>十
字キー\c<$0F>で羽根を動かし、\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を
押します。
column6: 1: Use the \c<$0B>D-Pad\c<$0F> to move the feather so it points to the \c<$0C>place name\c<$0F> to fill in, and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
２：書き込む\c<$0C>場所\c<$0F>を指すように、\c<$0B>十
字キー\c<$0F>で地図上の羽根を動かして、\c<$0B>
[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押します。
column6: 2: Use the \c<$0B>D-Pad\c<$0F> to move the feather so it points to the \c<$0C>area\c<$0F> to fill in, and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
３：書き込みを\c<$0C>中止\c<$0F>する時は、\c<$0B>終了\c<$0F>
に羽根を合わせて\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押すか\c<$0B>
[II]ボタン\c<$0F>を押して下さい。
column6: 3: To \c<$0C>stop\c<$0F> filling in, move the feather to \c<$0B>Done\c<$0F> and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>, or press the \c<$0B>II Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
画面の下に表示される地名の
色は、次のような意味を持っていま
す。
column6: The place names displayed at the bottom of the screen have the following meanings.

column5: \c<$09>黄色\c<$0F>‥地名を書き込んでいない。
column6: \c<$09>Yellow:\c<$0F> You haven't filled in the place name.

column5:
\c<$08>緑色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ後。\n
正しいか否かが確認できていない。
column6: \c<$08>Green:\c<$0F> Filled in. Whether it's correct or not is unconfirmed.

column5:
\c<$0A>赤色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ場所が、間違って
いる。
column6: \c<$0A>Red:\c<$0F> The location you filled in is incorrect.

column5: \c<$0F>白色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ場所が正しかった
column6: \c<$0F>White:\c<$0F> The location you filled in was correct.

column5:
外に出た時に、ナビが地図を
表示します。
column6: When you leave, Navi will display the map.

column5:
画面上の羽根を、行きたい場
所にあわせて、\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押してく
ださい。
column6: Move the on-screen feather to the place you want to go and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
柳　素子　（やなぎ　もとこ）\n
１６歳の女優。あの事件以来、ボク
の悪友。
column6:
Motoko Yanagi\n
A 16-year-old actress. My partner-in-crime since the incident.

column5:
四角形の\c<$0C>１辺は５００メート
ル\c<$0F>です。
column6: \c<$0C>One square\c<$0F> on the grid is \c<$0C>500 meters\c<$0F>.

column5:
立花　次郎　（たちばな　じろう）
刑事さん。でも、実績から見ると、
あまり頼りになりそうにないなぁ‥
column6:
Jirou Tachibana\n
A police detective. But based on his track record, he doesn't seem too reliable...

column5:
朝霧　正臣　（あさぎり　まさみ）
温子さんの夫。指輪事件も解決でき
て、幸せの新婚旅行の真っ最中。
column6:
Masami Asagiri\n
Atsuko's husband. With the ring incident resolved, he's in the middle of a happy honeymoon.

column5:
朝霧　温子　（あさぎり　あつこ）
正臣さんの奥さん。指輪も取り戻せ
たし、よかったよかった。
column6:
Atsuko Asagiri\n
Masami's wife. What a relief we were able to return her ring!

column5:
木原　尚子　（きはら　なおこ）\n
ハ虫類研究者。児島にいる珍種のヘ
ビを捕まえるのが目的なんだって。
column6:
Naoko Kihara\n
A reptile researcher. Says her goal is to capture rare snake species that are on Kojima.

column5:
渡部　吟次　（わたべ　ぎんじ）\n
児島の駐在さん。人当りのいい温厚
そうなおじいさん。
column6:
Ginji Watabe\n
Kojima's resident officer. Seems like an affable, mild-mannered old man.

column5:
老婆\n
鎌を振り回す、謎のお婆さん。あま
りお近付きにはなりたくないなぁ。
column6:
Old Woman\n
A mysterious old woman brandishing a sickle. I'd rather not get too close to her...

column5:
青年\n
名前は村野さん。ちょっと無愛想で
感じがいいとは言えないなぁ。
column6:
Young Man\n
His name is Murano. He's a bit brusque, and I can't say he gives off a pleasant mood.

column5:
榊　弘司　（さかき　こうじ）\n
児島ホテルのオーナー。\n
礼儀正しい紳士さん。
column6:
Kouji Sakaki\n
The owner of the Kojima Hotel.\n
A well-mannered gentleman.

column5:
やぁれやれ、あとは大島に戻
りゃぁ、今日の仕事は終りだ。
column6: Good grief. Just the trip back to Ohshima and work's over for today.

column5: ‥鎌がありませんね。
column6: ...The sickle's gone.

column5:
留守みたいですね。\n
‥鍵もかかってますよ。
column6:
It looks like he's not here.\n
...And it's locked.

column5: な‥なによ、これ!!
column6: Wh...what is THIS!?

column5: 無線機が壊されてますね。
column6: The transceiver's been destroyed.

column5:
落ち着いてる場合?!\n
早く知らせないと!!
column6: Is this any time to be calm!? We've got to hurry and tell someone!

column5:
渡部さんは留守の様ですが‥
それにしても誰が何の目的で、こん
な事をしたんでしょう？
column6: Mr. Watabe seems to be gone...But never mind that. Who would have done this and why?
column7: NOTE: this is actually an interesting question, and never properly explained. it's clear that Mutou/Murano was responsible (we see him running away from the station), but there's no obvious need for him to destroy the radio. the reason he came to the station in the first place was to retrieve the sickle, which contained a message from his grandmother giving the location of the syndicate's hideout (why couldn't she just meet him personally while he was there, though?). then he went to the noctilucent cave for reasons unknown and got murdered. the radio never really factors into things. perhaps it was simply to deflect attention away from the theft of the sickle, which was his real goal?

column5:
待ち切れずに食事にしようか
と話してた所だったんです。\n
さ、行きましょう。
column6: We were just discussing whether we should go ahead and eat without waiting for you. Come on, let's go.
column7:
NOTE: if you saw any of the optional dialogues earlier where they invite you to dinner.

also, there's an unused line that would have come right before this: 正臣「や！ちょうど良かった。
but instead they just reused the very similar line below.

column5:
これから、食事にしようかと
話してた所だったんですけどね。\n
どうです？ご一緒しませんか。
column6: We were just talking about going to eat, you see. So, why don't we go together?
column7: NOTE: if you haven't been invited already

column5:
え‥で、でも、お邪魔になる
から‥。
column6: Huh? B-but we'd be intruding...

column5:
とんでもない！\n
大勢の方が、楽しいですよ。\n
さ、行きましょう！
column6:
Preposterous!\n
It's more fun with a crowd. Come on, let's go!

column5: 気がついてよかったですよ。
column6: I'm glad I noticed you.

column5: ちょうど良かった。
column6: You came at the perfect time.

column5:
‥‥‥でね、とってもきれい
だったのよ！
column6: ...and let me tell you, it was just SO pretty!

column5:
夜光洞ですか‥いいなぁ。\n
ね、あなた。わたし達も後で行って
みましょうよ。
column6: The Noctilucent Cave...How nice. Hey, honey[nbsp]-- after this, why don't we go too?

column5:
やれやれ、夜光洞を見るまで
眠れないって顔してるね。
column6: Oh boy. That face tells me we're not sleeping until we've seen the Noctilucent Cave.

column5:
しょうがないなぁ‥。\n
日が暮れないうちに行ってみるか。
column6: I guess I don't have a choice here...Why don't we go before the sun's set?

column5:
それでは、ぼく達はこれで失
礼します。
column6: Well, we'll be off, then.

column5: それでは、失礼します。
column6: See you later, then.

column5:
今日は、ほんとに楽しかった
ですわ。
column6: Today was just so fun.

column5: おや、どうしたんです？
column6: Oh, what's the matter?

column5:
え‥いえ、よ、用なんてない
んです‥お、おジャマしました！
column6: Er...No, I-I don't really need anything...Excuse me!

column5:
？？\n
はぁ‥それでは、失礼します。
column6:
??\n
(sigh)...Well, goodbye.

column5: は〜い！
column6: Yeeees?

column5:
あ、あら‥メイさん？\n
また、お会いしましたね。
column6:
O-oh...May?\n
So we meet again.

column5:
木原さん?!\n
ど、どうしてここに？\n
‥それに、その姿?!
column6:
Ms. Kihara!?\n
Wh-what're you doing here!?...And why do you look like _that_!?

column5:
‥おおげさですねぇ。\n
可愛いヘビちゃんたちに、ご飯をあ
げてただけなのに‥。
column6:
Oh, you're so over-the-top.\n
I was just giving my cute snakies their food...

column5:
それに、この島にいる珍しい
ヘビちゃん達を捕まえるのが、私の
目的なんですけど。
column6: And my reason for coming to this island was to catch rare snakies that live here.

column5: は、はぁ‥。
column6: (s-sigh)...

column5:
あ！\n
ヘビちゃんたちが待ってるから。\n
それじゃ、失礼しますね。
column6:
Ah! My snakies are waiting.\n
Well, bye!

column5: た‥立花さん？
column6: M...Mr. Tachibana?

column5:
みんな、このホテルに来るん
ですねぇ。
column6: Seems like everyone comes to this hotel, huh?

column5:
それにしても立花さんは、元
気がなさそうですねぇ。\n
‥寂しそうに、お酒飲んでますよ。
column6: But never mind that. Mr. Tachibana looks unhappy. He has a forlorn expression, and he's drinking.

column5: ‥‥メイか。
column6: ...May.

column5: なんだ、気が付いてたんだ。
column6: Oh, you noticed us.

column5:
当り前だ‥。\n
これでも刑事なんだからな。
column6:
Of course...\n
Despite everything, I'm a detective.

column5:
ふん‥刑事か。\n
因果な商売だ‥。
column6:
Hmph...A detective, huh.\n
What a cursed calling...

column5:
何度も仏さんをおがんでいる
くせに、娘の‥最期の顔すら見てや
ることもできん‥‥。
column6: Again and again I reverence the Buddha, yet I can never see...my daughter's face...even her last moments...

column5: ‥娘さん、亡くなったの‥？
column6: ...You lost your daughter...?

column5:
ふふ‥‥草薙の娘にしては、
鈍いな。
column6: Heh...For Kusanagi's girl, you're slow to catch on.

column5: そ、そのペンダント‥‥。
column6: Th-that pendant...

column5:
思い出すね‥。\n
綾華が、よくお前さんの事を話して
た‥‥。
column6:
I remember...\n
Ayaka would always talk about you...

column5:
‥お前さんが、あの草薙英二
の娘だと知ったときは、さすがのお
れも驚いたな。
column6: ...Even I was surprised to find out you were Eiji Kusanagi's daughter.

column5: お父さんを‥知ってるの‥？
column6: You know about...my father...?

column5:
ああ‥よく、な。\n
草薙とおれは同期でね。\n
よくペアを組まされたもんだ。
column6:
Yeah...I knew him well.\n
Kusanagi and me were in the same year. We got paired up a lot.

column5:
もう一人、武藤ってやつがい
たんだが‥３人で何度も危ない橋を
渡ったよ。
column6: There was one more, a guy called Mutou...The three of us pulled through against danger after danger.

column5:
だが‥武藤も、草薙も、おれ
を残して逝っちまった‥‥‥‥。
column6: But...Mutou, Kusanagi, they've all gone and left me behind...
column7:
NOTE: random amusing fact observed while looking through the data: there's an unreferenced bit of text in the script data that comes after this line:
立花「‥バカな奴だよ、\c[subimg]森山\c[targetbox1]は‥。こんなに\c[subimg]重要な台詞\c[targetbox1]だったのに‥何で、\c[subimg]収録し忘れた\c[targetbox1]んだ‥‥。

Tachibana: "That dumbass Moriyama...Even though it was such an important line...How did (s)he forget to record it...?"

"moriyama" refers to game director 森山豊治/Moriyama Toyoharu. apparently, someone forgot to record a line here. wonder if they went back and recorded it or just cut it?

column5: メイ！
column6: May!

column5: ‥‥綾華の事‥ありがとう。
column6: ...Thank you...for Ayaka.

column5: ‥‥‥綾華‥お父さん‥‥。
column6: ...Ayaka...Father...

column5: メイ‥‥。
column6: May...

column5:
みんなボクの大事な人なのに
‥どうして、死んじゃったんだろ‥
column6: They're all so dear so me, so why...why did they have to die...?

column5:
‥大事な人なら、まだ‥たく
さん、素子だっているじゃないです
か！
column6:
...If you're thinking about people dear to you, there are still...so many.\n
You have Motoko, don't you!?

column5: 元気を、出してください‥。
column6: Please, cheer up...

column5:
‥‥‥へぇ、励ましてくれて
るんだ。
column6: ...Huh. You're trying to encourage me.

column5:
ナ、ナビは機械ですけど‥、
そ、それでも、メイはナビにとって
大事な人ですから‥‥。
column6: N-Navi is a machine, but...May, you're still a dear person to Navi...

column5:
め、迷惑かもしれませんけど
‥‥‥‥‥‥。
column6: A-although I may be a bother...

column5:
‥‥ううん、そんな事ない。
ナビも素子も、ボクの大事な人だよ
‥‥ありがとう。
column6:
...No, it's not like that.\n
You and Motoko both, Navi[nbsp]-- you're dear to me...Thank you.

column5:
さて！\n
それじゃ、元気を出していこうか!!
column6:
Okay!\n
Now, how about we cheer up!?

column5: さっきは、すまなかったな‥
column6: Sorry for earlier...

column5: いいんです。
column6: It's fine.

column5:
それより‥前からボクの事、
知ってたんでしょ？\n
どうして、教えてくれなかったの？
column6: But...you knew about me from the start, right? Why didn't you say something?

column5:
‥‥おれは、綾華の葬式にも
出られなかった男だぞ。\n
酒でも飲まなけりゃ、言えるもんか
column6: ...I'm a man who couldn't even go to Ayaka's funeral. As if I'd be able to say anything without a drink in me.

column5:
そうだ。言い忘れていたが、
あまり、この島に長居をするな。
column6: That's right. I forgot to say this, but don't stick around on this island too long.

column5: え？‥どうして?!
column6: Huh?...Why not!?

column5:
秘密だ。\n
とにかく、早めに帰った方がいい。
column6:
It's a secret.\n
Anyway, you should head home early.

column5:
人の言うことは、素直に聞い
ておけって。\n
とにかく、早めに帰るんだ。
column6: Look, you should heed what you're told. Just go home early.

column5: 返事がありませんね。
column6: There's no response.

column5:
素子ってば‥どこ行っちゃっ
たんだろ？
column6: That Motoko...Where could she have gone?

column5: メモが張ってありますよ。
column6: There's a note stuck here.

column5: 素子からだ‥‥なになに？
column6: It's from Motoko...What's it say?

column5:
メイへ。\n
温子さん達を、夜光洞まで案内して
くるわね。　　　　　　　素子[heart]
column6:
May[nbsp]--\n
Going to go lead the Asagiris to the Noctilucent Cave.[nbsp]-- Motoko[nbsp][heart]

column5:
ふぅ‥。\n
いや、何でもないんじゃよ。
column6:
(sigh)...\n
Ah, it's nothing.

column5:
あのぉ‥言いにくい事なんで
すけど、駐在所の無線機がですね。
壊されてたんですが‥。
column6: Umm...It's hard to say this, but about the transceiver at the substation...It's been destroyed.

column5:
な？\n
[2x]\s<$01>なんじゃと?!
column6:
Wha...?[br3]
[2x]\s<$01>What in tarnation!?[1x]

column5:
へぇ、こんな所に浜辺があっ
たんだ。
column6: Ooh...So there's a beach somewhere like this.

column5:
周囲が岩場に囲まれてますか
ら、ちょっと見ただけでは分かりま
せんね。
column6: The surrounding area is enclosed by rocks, so you wouldn't know it at a glance.

column5: ‥無惨なものですねぇ。
column6: What a cruel deed.

column5: うっわぁ‥これはヒドイ。
column6: Wah...This is awful.

column5:
これは、もうダメですね。\n
それにしても、誰が何の目的で、こ
んな事をしたんでしょう？
column6:
It's done for.\n
But who would do something like this, and why?

column5:
めちゃめちゃじゃ‥‥。\n
もう‥この無線は使えんのぉ‥‥。
だれが、こんな事を‥‥。
column6:
It's in shambles, it is...\n
We can't use this radio anymore...Who in the world would...?

column5: な、なに今の?!
column6: Wh-what was that!?

column5:
叫び声みたいでした。\n
発生源は洞窟の中です。
column6:
It sounded like a scream.\n
It came from inside the cave.

column5:
い‥\n
[2x]\s<$01>いぃやあぁぁっ！
column6:
N...[br3]
[2x]\s<$01>NOOOOOOOOO![1x]

column5: ち、違うの！私じゃないわ!!
column6: N-no! It wasn't me!

column5:
け、け、警察を‥警察を呼ん
できます!!
column6: Th-th-the police...I'll go call the police!

column5: わ、わた‥し‥私は‥‥‥。

村野くん‥‥。\n
かわいそうにのぉ‥‥。
column6:
Young Murano...\n
Poor boy...

column5:
そんな！\n
素子が‥素子が、こんな事するはず
ないよっ!!
column6:
No!\n
Motoko would...Motoko would NEVER do something like this!

column5: と言われてものぉ。
column6: My hands are tied.

column5:
凶器の鎌は‥この子が持って
いたのじゃろ？
column6: The sickle that was the murder weapon...wasn't this girl holding it?

column5:
‥気の毒じゃが、このまま帰
すわけには、いかんのじゃよ。
column6: It pains me, but things being what they are, I just can't let her go.

column5: ともかくじゃ。
column6: Letting that alone...

column5:
駐在所の無線機が誰かに壊さ
れたおかげで、わし一人で調べねば
ならんのじゃよ。
column6: What with the transceiver in the substation being busted, I'm gonna have to investigate this on my lonesome.

column5:
皆さんに、協力をお願いしま
すぞ。
column6: All of you, please cooperate with me.

column5: これで、よし‥。
column6: Right, there's that done...

column5:
調査は明日から始めますでの
今日の所は、帰って頂いて結構です
じゃ。
column6: I'll start investigating tomorrow. You can all go home for today.

column5:
それでは、素子くん。\n
行きますかの。
column6: Now then, Miss Motoko. Let's be off.

column5:
‥気の毒じゃが。\n
素子くんには、しばらく駐在所に寝
泊まりしてもらう事になるのぉ。
column6:
It pains me, but...\n
For now, I'll be having Miss Motoko stay the night at the substation.
M-May...

column5: 大丈夫だよ、素子。
column6: It'll be all right, Motoko.

column5:
ボクが素子の無実を証明して
あげる。後で、駐在所まで会いに行
くから‥待ってて。
column6: I'll prove you're innocent. I'll come by the substation to see you later, so...wait for me.

column5:
はぁ‥‥とんでもないことに
なってしまいました。
column6: (sigh)...This has turned into something just awful.

column5:
素子さんの他には、人の姿を
見てませんし‥‥。
column6: I didn't see anyone other than Motoko...

column5:
ほんとに‥‥素子さんが犯人
なんでしょうか？
column6: Could she really be the culprit?

column7: NOTE: this is presumably atsuko's line if you talk to her as she and masami are walking away from the cave, but i'm pretty sure it's impossible to get to her fast enough -- you can just barely catch masami right as he's going off screen, and that's only if you make a dash for him the instant you regain control (in a sequence where most players probably won't even realize you can move)

column5:
ごゆっくり、おくつろ
ぎください。
column6: Please relax and make yourself at home.

column5:
ご用がございましたら
承ります。
column6: Should you need anything, I'll be right with you.

column5: はい。何でしょう？
column6: Yes? What do you need?

column5:
観光名所のこと　夜光洞のこと\n
天狗岩のこと　　立ち去る
column6:
Tourist sites
[sp]<$70>
Noctilucent Cave
\n

Tengu Rock
[sp]<$70>
Leave

column5:
観光名所のこと　浜辺のこと\n
夜光洞のこと　　天狗岩のこと\n
立ち去る
column6:
Tourist sites
[sp]<$70>
Beach
\n

Noctilucent Cave
[sp]<$70>
Tengu Rock
\n

Leave

column5:
有名な観光名所には、\c<$0C>
夜光洞\c<$0F>、それに\c<$0C>天狗岩\c<$0F>がございます
column6: When it comes to well-known sightseeing locations, there is the \c<$0C>Noctilucent Cave\c<$0F>, as well as \c<$0C>Tengu Rock\c<$0F>.

column5:
児島の海は、大変きれ
いですよ。
column6: Kojima's sea is extraordinarily pretty.

column5:
西側の海岸が、浜辺に
なってますから、おいでになっては
いかがでしょう。
column6: The western side is beach, so why don't you try going there?

column5:
ここはお勧めしますわ
夜光洞を見ないお客様は、おられま
せんもの。
column6: That one is my recommendation. There isn't a guest that doesn't see the Noctilucent Cave.

column5:
海上に突き出ている大
きな一枚岩が天狗岩なんです。\n
\c<$0C>岬からの眺め\c<$0F>が一番ですわ。
column6: The big rock slab projecting from the sea is Tengu Rock. The \c<$0C>view from the cape\c<$0F> is the best.

column5:
お客様。\n
申し訳ございませんが、この先にお
通しする訳にはまいりません。
column6:
Ma'am.\n
I'm terribly sorry, but coming back here is not permitted.

column5:
この岩場の向こうが、港だよ
ね？
column6: So the harbor's on the other side of these rocks?

column5:
そうですよ。\n
‥とは言っても、この険しい岩場の
５００メートル先ですけどね。
column6:
That's right.\n
...Though it's 500 meters away over steep rock.

column5:
ロープですか？\n
海から流れ着いたんでしょうか。
column6:
Is that a rope?\n
Maybe it washed in from the sea.

column5:
ロープの端が岩場に結び付け
られてるからね。\n
誰かが結んだのは間違いないよ。
column6: The rope's end is attached to the rocks. Someone definitely tied it there.

column5:
ま、たいして意味はないだろ
うけどね。
column6: Oh well, I doubt there's really any significance to it.

column5: 鍵がかかってますね。
column6: It's locked.

column5:
‥‥素子くんといったかの。
すまんが、駐在所まで来てもらおう
かの。
column6:
...Miss Motoko, was it?\n
Sorry, but could I ask you to come to the substation?

column5:
ロープで封鎖されてて‥入っ
てはいけないのでは？
column6: It's blocked off with rope...Are we not allowed in?

column5:
一人で泳いだって楽しくない
もんね‥‥。
column6: It wouldn't be any fun swimming by myself...

column5:
セーブ　　　　　人物\n
設定　　　　　　コマンド終了

\n

column5: セーブしました。
column6: Saved.

\n

column5: 順を追って説明しますね。
column6: I'll explain in order.

column5:
１：書き込む\c<$0C>地名\c<$0F>を指すように、\c<$0B>十
字キー\c<$0F>で羽根を動かし、\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を
押します。
column6: 1: Use the \c<$0B>D-Pad\c<$0F> to move the feather so it points to the \c<$0C>place name\c<$0F> to fill in, and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
２：書き込む\c<$0C>場所\c<$0F>を指すように、\c<$0B>十
字キー\c<$0F>で地図上の羽根を動かして、\c<$0B>
[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押します。
column6: 2: Use the \c<$0B>D-Pad\c<$0F> to move the feather so it points to the \c<$0C>area\c<$0F> to fill in, and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
３：書き込みを\c<$0C>中止\c<$0F>する時は、\c<$0B>終了\c<$0F>
に羽根を合わせて\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押すか\c<$0B>
[II]ボタン\c<$0F>を押して下さい。
column6: 3: To \c<$0C>stop\c<$0F> filling in, move the feather to \c<$0B>Done\c<$0F> and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>, or press the \c<$0B>II Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
画面の下に表示される地名の
色は、次のような意味を持っていま
す。
column6: The place names displayed at the bottom of the screen have the following meanings.

column5: \c<$09>黄色\c<$0F>‥地名を書き込んでいない。
column6: \c<$09>Yellow:\c<$0F> You haven't filled in the place name.

column5:
\c<$08>緑色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ後。\n
正しいか否かが確認できていない。
column6: \c<$08>Green:\c<$0F> Filled in. Whether it's correct or not is unconfirmed.

column5:
\c<$0A>赤色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ場所が、間違って
いる。
column6: \c<$0A>Red:\c<$0F> The location you filled in is incorrect.

column5: \c<$0F>白色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ場所が正しかった
column6: \c<$0F>White:\c<$0F> The location you filled in was correct.

column5:
外に出た時に、ナビが地図を
表示します。
column6: When you leave, Navi will display the map.

column5:
画面上の羽根を、行きたい場
所にあわせて、\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押してく
ださい。
column6: Move the on-screen feather to the place you want to go and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
柳　素子　（やなぎ　もとこ）\n
１６歳の女優。あの事件以来、ボク
の悪友。
column6:
Motoko Yanagi\n
A 16-year-old actress. My partner-in-crime since the incident.

column5:
柳　素子　（やなぎ　もとこ）\n
まさか、素子が人殺し?!\n
そんなはずないよっ！
column6:
Motoko Yanagi\n
No way[nbsp]-- Motoko, a murderer!?\n
That's impossible!

column5:
立花　次郎　（たちばな　じろう）
刑事さん。でも、実績から見ると、
あまり頼りになりそうにないなぁ‥
column6:
Jirou Tachibana\n
A police detective. But based on his track record, he doesn't seem too reliable...

column5:
立花　次郎　（たちばな　じろう）
刑事さん。実は綾華のお父さんだっ
たんだよね‥。
column6:
Jirou Tachibana\n
A police detective. So he was actually Ayaka's father...

column5:
朝霧　正臣　（あさぎり　まさみ）
温子さんの夫。指輪事件も解決でき
て、幸せの新婚旅行の真っ最中。
column6:
Masami Asagiri\n
Atsuko's husband. With the ring incident resolved, he's in the middle of a happy honeymoon.

column5:
朝霧　正臣　（あさぎり　まさみ）
温子さんの夫。新婚旅行で２つもの
事件に巻き込まれた不運の人。
column6:
Masami Aasagiri\n
Atsuko's husband. An unlucky man who's gotten caught up in two incidents on his honeymoon.

column5:
朝霧　温子　（あさぎり　あつこ）
正臣さんの奥さん。指輪も取り戻せ
たし、よかったよかった。
column6:
Atsuko Asagiri\n
Masami's wife. What a relief we were able to return her ring!

column5:
朝霧　温子　（あさぎり　あつこ）
正臣さんの奥さん。せっかくの新婚
旅行だったのに‥不幸な人だよね。
column6:
Atsuko Asagiri\n
Masami's wife. She'd finally gotten to go on her honeymoon, but now...What an unfortunate woman.

column5:
木原　尚子　（きはら　なおこ）\n
ハ虫類研究者。児島にいる珍種のヘ
ビを捕まえるのが目的なんだって。
column6:
Naoko Kihara\n
A reptile researcher. Says her goal is to capture rare snake species that are on Kojima.

column5:
渡部　吟次　（わたべ　ぎんじ）\n
児島の駐在さん。人当りのいい温厚
そうなおじいさん。
column6:
Ginji Watabe\n
Kojima's resident officer. Seems like an affable, mild-mannered old man.

column5:
老婆\n
鎌を振り回す、謎のお婆さん。あま
りお近付きにはなりたくないなぁ。
column6:
Old Woman\n
A mysterious old woman brandishing a sickle. I'd rather not get too close to her...

column5:
青年\n
名前は村野さん。ちょっと無愛想で
感じがいいとは言えないなぁ。
column6:
Young Man\n
His name is Murano. He's a bit brusque, and I can't say he gives off a pleasant mood.

column5:
榊　弘司　（さかき　こうじ）\n
児島ホテルのオーナー。\n
礼儀正しい紳士さん。
column6:
Kouji Sakaki\n
The owner of the Kojima Hotel.\n
A well-mannered gentleman.

column5:
四角形の\c<$0C>１辺は５００メート
ル\c<$0F>です。
column6: \c<$0C>One square\c<$0F> on the grid is \c<$0C>500 meters\c<$0F>.

column5:
てんぐいわ）\n
花コウ岩でできた巨岩塔。
column6:
Tengu Rock\n
An enormous rock tower made of granite.

column5:
海上からの高さは、１１．４ｍにも
達します。
column6: It extends 11.4 meters above sea level.

column5:
その昔、児島の天狗と大島の天狗が
力を競い合った時に、児島天狗が投
げた岩であると伝えられています。
岬の先端から、眺めることができま
す。
column6:
Legend tells that in ancient times, when the tengu of Kojima had a contest of might with the tengu of Ohshima, the Kojima tengu threw this rock.
[wait][clear]

You can look out upon it from the tip of the cape.

column5: ‥こっちは裏ですって。
column6: ...Hey, this is the back.

column5:
メイ！\n
照明をつけてませんよ。
column6:
May!\n
The lights aren't on.

column5:
やこうどう）\n
夜光ゴケが自生する洞窟です。
column6:
Noctilucent Cave\n
A cave where noctilucent moss grows natively.

column5:
夜光ゴケはセン類に属するコケ植物
であり、発光する性質を持っている
珍しい植物です。
column6: Noctilucent moss is a bryophyte with the unusual property of emitting light.

column5:
発光のために微量元素を必要とする
ため、自生域は限られています。
column6: Because it requires micronutrients for the emission of light, its native range is limited.

column5:
夜光洞では、洞窟の奥に備えられた
スイッチで照明を消すことができま
す。
column6: In Noctilucent Cave, you can turn off the lights using the switch installed within the cave.

column5:
夜光ゴケと岩石に含まれる鉱物が闇
に放つ光が、幻想的な世界をつくり
あげます。
column6: The light given off by the noctilucent moss and the minerals in the rocks creates a fantastic world.

column5:
←照明用スイッチ\n
消した後は、必ずつけるようにして
ください。
column6:
[<-] Light Switch\n
After turning off, please be sure to turn back on.

column5:
へぇ、こんな所に浜辺があっ
たんだ。
column6: Ooh...So there's a beach somewhere like this.

column5:
周囲が岩場に囲まれてますか
ら、ちょっと見ただけでは分かりま
せんね。
column6: The surrounding area is enclosed by rocks, so you wouldn't know it at a glance.

column5:
この岩場の向こうが、港だよ
ね？
column6: So the harbor's on the other side of these rocks?

column5:
そうですよ。\n
‥とは言っても、この険しい岩場の
５００メートル先ですけどね。
column6:
That's right.\n
...Though it's 500 meters away over steep rock.

column5:
ロープですか？\n
海から流れ着いたんでしょうか。
column6:
Is that a rope?\n
Maybe it washed in from the sea.

column5:
ロープの端が岩場に結び付け
られてるからね。\n
誰かが結んだのは間違いないよ。
column6: The rope's end is attached to the rocks. Someone definitely tied it there.

column5:
ま、たいして意味はないだろ
うけどね。
column6: Oh well, I doubt there's really any significance to it.

column5:
ごゆっくり、おくつろ
ぎください。
column6: Please relax and make yourself at home.

column5:
ご用がございましたら
承ります。
column6: Should you need anything, I'll be right with you.

column5: はい。何でしょう？
column6: Yes? What do you need?

column5:
観光名所のこと　夜光洞のこと\n
天狗岩のこと　　立ち去る

[sp]<$70>
Noctilucent Cave
\n

Tengu Rock
[sp]<$70>

column5:

夜光洞のこと　　天狗岩のこと\n

Beach
\n

Noctilucent Cave
[sp]<$70>

\n

column5:
有名な観光名所には、\c<$0C>
夜光洞\c<$0F>、それに\c<$0C>天狗岩\c<$0F>がございます
column6: When it comes to well-known sightseeing locations, there is the \c<$0C>Noctilucent Cave\c<$0F>, as well as \c<$0C>Tengu Rock\c<$0F>.

column5:
児島の海は、大変きれ
いですよ。
column6: Kojima's sea is extraordinarily pretty.

column5:
西側の海岸が、浜辺に
なってますから、おいでになっては
いかがでしょう。
column6: The western side is beach, so why don't you try going there?

column5:
ここはお勧めしますわ
夜光洞を見ないお客様は、おられま
せんもの。
column6: That one is my recommendation. There isn't a guest that doesn't see the Noctilucent Cave.

column5:
海上に突き出ている大
きな一枚岩が天狗岩なんです。\n
\c<$0C>岬からの眺め\c<$0F>が一番ですわ。
column6: The big rock slab projecting from the sea is Tengu Rock. The \c<$0C>view from the cape\c<$0F> is the best.

column5:
お客様。\n
申し訳ございませんが、この先にお
通しする訳にはまいりません。
column6:
Ma'am.\n
I'm terribly sorry, but coming back here is not permitted.

column5:
遊んでいる場合じゃないよね
早く、素子を助けてあげないと‥。
column6: This is no time to play around. I have to hurry and help Motoko...!

column5: 立花さん、いませんね。
column6: Mr. Tachibana isn't here.

column5:
もぉっ！\n
肝心な時に、役に立たないんだから
なぁ。
column6:
Ugh!\n
Whenever it's something important, he's useless.

column5: 立花さん!!
column6: MR. TACHIBANA!

column5:
おいおい、おどかすなよ。\n
血相を変えて、一体どうしたんだ？
column6: Hey hey, don't startle me like that. The heck's got you in such a tizzy?

column5:
それどころじゃないよ!!\n
素子が‥素子が捕まっちゃったんだ
よっ！
column6:
This isn't the time!\n
Motoko's...Motoko's been arrested!

column5: とにかく落ち着け。
column6: Okay, calm down.

column5:
あまり、大声で話せる様な事
じゃなさそうだからな。\n
とりあえず、おれの部屋に来い。
column6:
This doesn't sound like something you can go yelling about.\n
Come to my room for now.

column5:
話を聞かせてもらおうじゃな
いか。
column6: I'll hear you out inside, all right?

column5:
‥‥‥‥‥‥なるほどね。\n
犯行に用いられた凶器を素子が持っ
ていたわけだ。
column6:
...Got it.\n
So Motoko was holding the murder weapon used in the crime.

column5:
でも‥素子が、そんな事をす
るわけないよ！
column6: But...there's no way Motoko would do something like this!

column5:
そいつは、まだ何とも言えん
な。
column6: I can't say anything about that yet.

column5:
が、ともかくだ。\n
事件をほっておく訳にもいかん。
column6: But whatever's happened, I can't just ignore a case.

column5:
まずは素子に話を聞いて、そ
れから現場だな。\n
メイ、案内してくれ。
column6: Guess we should talk to Motoko first, then check the crime scene. May, you lead the way.

column5:
ドアノブにプレートが掛かっ
てますよ。\n
『起こさないで！』だそうですが‥
column6: There's a plate attached to the doorknob. It says `Do Not Wake!~...
column7: NOTE: the graphic actually says 起こさないで下さい (same except for adding 下さい)

column5:
ふぅ‥。\n
ショックで寝込んじゃったかなぁ‥
column6:
(sigh)...\n
Maybe they're in bed from the shock...

column5:
ダメです。\n
鍵がかかってますよ。
column6: It's no use. It's locked.

column5: メイ‥メイなの?!
column6: May...May, is that you!?

column5:
よかった‥。\n
無事だったんだね、素子。
column6:
Thank goodness...\n
So you're safe, Motoko.

column5:
事件が起こった時の事を聞き
たいんだけど、いいかな？
column6: I want to ask you about the incident, if that's okay?

column5: メイ?!
column6: May!?

column5:
鍵がかかってるんです。\n
扉ごしになら話せそうですけどね。
column6:
It's locked.\n
It looks like we can talk through the door, though.

column5:
話せるだけではダメだ。\n
窓からでも何でもいい、じかに姿を
見て話さないとな。
column6: Just being able to talk's not gonna cut it. We need to converse face-to-face, even if it's through a window.

column5:
素子、無事？\n
もう少し‥もう少しだけ待ってて。
必ず助けてあげるから！
column6:
Motoko, are you okay?\n
Please wait just...just a little longer. I WILL help you!

column5:
ともかく、扉ごしに話せるだ
けではダメだ。
column6: Look, just talking through the door's not gonna cut it.

column5:
\c<$0C>窓から\c<$0F>でも何でもいい、じか
に姿を見て話さないとな。
column6: Even talking \c<$0C>through the window\c<$0F> is fine, but we need to converse face-to-face.

column5: メイ！‥‥立花さんも。
column6: MAY!...And Mr. Tachibana.

column5:
やれやれ、おまけ扱いかよ‥
悲しいねぇ。
column6: Geez, tacking me on as an extra...So sad.

column5:
ま、いいや。\n
ところで、少しばかり聞きたい事が
あるんだがな。
column6:
Ah, whatever.\n
We'd like to ask you a thing or two, all right?

column5:
渡部さんは？\n
‥どこ行ったの。
column6: Where's Mr. Watabe? Did he go somewhere?

column5:
この部屋で待っているのじゃ
ぞって言って‥、そのまま外に出て
行ったけど‥。
column6: He told me to stay put in this room...and then he went out and left me here...

column5: それっきり姿を見てないわ。
column6: I haven't seen him since.

column5: 渡部‥？‥‥‥まさかな。
column6: Watabe...? ...I wonder.

column5:
‥温子さん達を案内した後に
ね。気をつかったつもりで、外に出
ようとしたの‥‥。
column6: It was after I'd led the Asagiris there. I thought I'd give them a little privacy and started to go outside...
column7: NOTE: just noting because this confused me for a second: she's "being considerate" by giving the newly married couple private time

column5:
でも、メイも聞いたでしょ？
叫び声が聞こえて、慌てて、その方
向を見てみたら‥。
column6: But you heard it too, right, May? There was a scream, and when I rushed in the direction it came from to look...

column5: み、見てみたら‥？
column6: Y-you saw...?

column5:
あの男の人が、倒れるところ
だったのよ。
column6: That man, collapsing to the ground.

column5:
それに、真っ暗で‥よく分か
らなかったけど、もう一人‥人影が
見えたような気もするわ。
column6: And in the pitch darkness...I couldn't really tell, but I feel like there was someone else...like I could see a silhouette.

column5:
倒れた男の人を見て、近付い
たんだけど‥。\n
その時には、まだ息があったわ。
column6: I saw the collapsed man and got closer, but...he was still breathing then.

column5:
お、おなかに、鎌が刺さって
て‥とても苦しんでた。
column6: Th-there was a sickle stabbed through his stomach...He was really suffering.

column5:
彼‥自分で鎌を抜いたのよ。
それを私に差し出して‥私、ぼ〜っ
としながら、それを受け取って‥。
column6: He...he pulled out the sickle on his own. He held it out to me, and...I was really out of it, and I took it...

column5: そこで、彼が力尽きた‥‥。
column6: Then, he ran out of strength...

column5:
素子‥絶対に助けてあげるか
ら‥。\n
だから‥もう少しだけ待ってて。
column6: Motoko...I'm going to help you, so...so...wait just a little longer.

column5:
ロープで封鎖されてて‥入っ
てはいけないのでは？
column6: It's blocked off with rope...Are we not allowed in?

column5:
かまわんさ。\n
おれが刑事だって事を、忘れてない
か？
column6:
We're fine.\n
You forgetting I'm a police detective?

column5: ん？‥ロープが濡れてるな。
column6: Hm?...The rope's wet.

column5:
？？\n
別に濡れるような事はしてないはず
だけど。
column6:
??\n
But nothing's really happened that would have gotten it wet.

column5: 暗くて見えませんよぉ。
column6: It's too dark to see.

column5:
多量の出血跡がありますね。
遺体の側には鎌が落ちてます。
column6: There are a large number of bloodstains. The sickle's been dropped next to the body.
column7: NOTE: she says this even if you've already picked it up

column5:
鎌は素子が落としたんだろ？
だったら、どこに落ちていようと事
件には関係ない。
column6: It was Motoko that dropped the sickle, yeah? Then where it fell's got nothing to do with the case.

column5:
この鎌‥駐在所で、お婆さん
が投げた鎌ですよね。
column6: This sickle...It's the one the old woman threw at the substation.

column5:
そいつは大事な証拠品だ。\n
押収しておけ。
column6: That's important evidence. Grab it.

column5:
それじゃ、持って行きましょ
うか。
column6: Okay then, let's take it with us.

column5:
なるほど‥腹部に刺し傷が認
められるな。
column6: I see...Looks like he's got a stab wound in his abdomen.

column5:
死因は出血多量によるショッ
ク死ってところか。
column6: I'm guessing the cause of death was shock induced by massive blood loss.

column5:
鎌を抜いたために出血が激し
くなり、血溜りを作ったと考えられ
るな。
column6: I'd say that the bleeding grew more severe when he pulled the sickle out, creating the puddle.

column5: 衣服がかなり乱れてるな‥。
column6: His clothes are pretty disheveled...

column5: 争った跡でしょうか？
column6: Was it from a struggle?

column5:
おそらくな。\n
かなり激しく争ったらしいな。
column6:
Safe bet.\n
Looks like he put up a pretty tough fight.

column5:
それに、服に夜光ゴケが付着
していることにも注目すべきだろう
column6: And we should probably pay attention to the noctilucent moss stuck to his clothes, too.

column5:
そういえば‥この辺りの地面
には、夜光ゴケは生えてないよね。
column6: Come to think of it...there's no noctilucent moss growing on the ground in this area, is there?

column5:
夜光ゴケの生えている壁際で
争ったんだろう。\n
コケは、その際に付着したらしいな
column6: They probably fought near a wall the noctilucent moss grows on. That would be when it got stuck on him.

column5:
たいして所持品はないな‥、
おっと！財布があったぞ。
column6:
Doesn't seem to have anything important on him...\n
Ah-ha! There's a wallet.

column5: お金を盗んじゃいけませんよ
column6: Stealing money isn't allowed.

column5:
バ、バカが！\n
刑事が、そんな事するものか！
column6:
I-idiot!\n
As if a detective would do that!

column5:
財布につまってるのは金じゃ
ない。
column6: It's not money that's in the wallet.

column5:
身分証明書などの重要な情報
が入ってるんだ‥‥。\n
そら！免許証があった。
column6:
His ID and other important information's in here...\n
There! Found his license.

column5:
どれどれ‥‥‥武藤孝弘。\n
生年月日からすれば‥え〜と１９才
か。
column6:
Let's see...Takahiro Mutou.\n
From his date of birth, he's...uh, 19.

column5:
‥あれ？確か、村野って名前
じゃなかったかな、この人。
column6: ...Huh? This guy[nbsp]-- wasn't his name Murano?

Mutou...[br3]
[2x]\s<$01>Is this a joke!?[1x]

column5:
この子が‥\n
武藤孝弘だとっ!!
column6: This kid is...Takahiro Mutou!?

column5: ‥もしかして、知り合い？
column6: ...Do you know him?

column5: そんな事があったんだ‥‥。
column6: So that's what happened...

column5:
その時、武藤には１２になる
子供がいてな‥。
column6: Back then, Mutou had a 12-year-old kid...

column5: まさか‥この人が？
column6: You don't mean...this man?
...That's right.

column5:
取り乱してしまったな。\n
これでは、刑事としては失格だ。
column6:
Guess I lost my cool there.\n
I'm not fit to be a detective like this.

column5:
被害者が誰であろうと関係な
い。\n
解決に全力をつくすだけだ。
column6: Who the victim is has nothing to do with it. All I can do is put everything I've got into solving this.

column5:
しかし‥なぜ彼がこんな島に
いたのか‥？\n
足取りを追ってみるべきかな‥‥。
column6: But...what was he doing on this island...? Maybe I should try to follow his trail...

column5:
おっと、大事な証拠品を忘れ
てるぞ。\n
鎌を押収しておいてくれ。
column6: Whoops, we're forgetting important evidence. Grab that sickle.

column5:
それじゃ、持って行きましょ
うか。
column6: Okay then, let's take it with us.

column5:
被害者を調べるだけでは、ど
うにもならん。\n
素子からも話を聞いてみないとな。
column6: Just investigating the victim's not going to get us anywhere. We've have to hear what Motoko's got to say.

column5:
さて、と。\n
素子の\c<$0C>無実を証明できそうなもの\c<$0F>は
見つかったか？
column6:
Right, then.\n
Have we found \c<$0C>something that looks like it could prove Motoko's innocence\c<$0F>?

column5:
‥メイ。\n
ほんっきでそう思ってるんですか？
column6:
...May.\n
Do you SERIOUSLY think that?

column5:
草薙よぉ。\n
お前にゃ悪いが、娘のデキはよくな
いぞ。
column6:
Oh, Kusanagi...\n
Hate to say it, but your daughter ain't the brightest bulb.

column5:
ええいっ！こうなりゃメイ。
お前が分かるまで調査を続けるぞ！
column6: All right! If that's what it's gonna take, May, then we'll just keep investigating until you get it!

column5:
お、いいところに目をつけた
な。もう一歩だ。
column6: Oh, we're closing in on something. One more step.
column7: NOTE: picking "clothes" without having unlocked the "moss" option

column5:
確かに、衣服には争った跡が
ある。
column6: Sure, his clothes have signs of a struggle.

column5:
だが、それだけでは彼が素子
と争ったのではない、との証拠には
なってないぞ。
column6: But that alone doesn't prove he didn't fight against Motoko.

column5: 衣服についてた夜光ゴケ‥。
column6: The noctilucent moss stuck to his clothes...

column5:
素子の服には夜光ゴケなんて
ついてなかったよね？
column6: There wasn't any stuck to Motoko's clothes, was there?

column5:
そうだ。これだけ激しく争っ
たならば、彼女の服にもコケがつい
ていて当然だろう。
column6: Right. If they'd fought that hard, we'd expect her clothes to have moss on them too.

column5:
コケが地面に落ちていないか
ら、払い落としたとも考えられない
column6: There's no moss on the ground, so it's not sensible to think she shook it off.

column5:
だから‥。\n
素子は犯人ではない‥？
column6: So...Motoko's not the murderer...?

column5:
だとしたら‥本当の犯人はど
こに？
column6: Then...where's the real culprit?

column5:
ボクも朝霧さん達もいたけど
犯人らしい人は見なかったよ！
column6: Both me and the Asagiris were there, but we didn't see anyone who looked like the killer!

column5:
よし。\n
それを考えようじゃないか。
column6:
All right.\n
Why don't we think about it?

column5:
それでは、犯人の行動を順に
考えて行きましょう。
column6: Okay then, let's consider the culprit's actions in sequence.

column5:
\c<$0B>[II]ボタン\c<$0F>を押して、\c<$0B>犯人の行
動\c<$0F>を実行してください。
column6: Press the \c<$0B>II Button\c<$0F>, and choose \c<$0B>Culprit's Actions\c<$0F>.

column5:
そうだろうな。\n
おれにも分からん。
column6:
Yeah, guess you're right.\n
I dunno either.
column7: NOTE: i can't imagine anyone really saw this; the ability to leave the investigate menu is only given after learning mutou's identity, so to encounter this, you have to go out of your way to pick the last option repeatedly while leaving others unchecked

column5:
わ、分からないなら聞かない
で下さい！
column6: I-if you don't know, then don't ask us!

column5:
怒るな怒るな。\n
十分に調べきった訳じゃないんだ。
必ず手がかりは見つかるって。
column6:
Hey now, don't get mad.\n
We didn't investigate enough. I'm sure we'll turn up a clue.

column5:
分からんか？\n
草薙の娘にしては、まだまだ鈍いぞ
column6:
Don't know?\n
For Kusanagi's daughter, you're pretty dull.

column5:
ま、いい。\n
お前が分かるまで調査を続けるとし
ようか。
column6:
Well, whatever.\n
How about we keep investigating until you get it?

column5:
何だろ‥ここだけ妙に地面が
濡れてるね。
column6: What's this...? The ground is strangely wet only right here.

column5:
地下でつながっている泉を泳
いで来た犯人が、この場所で泉から
あがったと考えられます。
column6: It's conceivable that the culprit, having swum in through the spring this one connects to underground, got out of it here.

column5:
で、ナビたちが夜光洞を去っ
てから、外に逃げたわけですね。
column6: Then, after Navi and the others left the Noctilucent Cave, they escaped outside.

column5:
この辺りの壁には、夜光ゴケ
が生えてないね。
column6: There's no noctilucent moss growing on the wall in this area.

column5:
かすかですけど‥血の跡があ
ります。まだ、そんなに時間がたっ
てませんね。
column6: They're faint, but...these are blood marks. Not much time has passed.
column7: NOTE: not much time since the marks were left, presumably, but she doesn't actually say that

column5:
壁の表面が、少し崩れかけて
います。夜光ゴケは剥がれてしまっ
たのでしょう。
column6: The wall's surface has collapsed slightly. The noctilucent moss has peeled off.

column5:
微かですけど、血痕も残され
てますよ。
column6: It's faint, but bloodstains have also been left here.

column5:
武藤さんと犯人が争っていた
場所です。
column6: This is where Mutou and the culprit fought.

column5:
夜光ゴケが剥がれている事、
そして何より残された血痕が、それ
を証明してます。
column6: The fact that the noctilucent moss has peeled off[nbsp]-- and more than anything, the bloodstains that were left[nbsp]-- prove that.

column5:
この辺りの壁が、妙な具合に
崩れてますね。
column6: The wall in this area has crumbled in a strange way.

column5:
ほら、この岩なんて人の顔に
見えます。
column6: Look[nbsp]-- this rock looks like a person's face.

column5:
まず、武藤さんと犯人が争っ
た場所を考えましょう。
column6: First, let's think about the location where Mutou and the culprit fought.

column5:
\c<$0B>６０秒以内\c<$0F>に、二人が争った
と考えられる地点で\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押し
てください。
column6: Press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F> at the location you believe the two fought \c<$0B>within 60 seconds\c<$0F>.

column5:
武藤さんと犯人が争ったと思
われる地点は既に判明しています。
犯人の次の行動を考えましょう。
column6: We've already established the location where we think Mutou and the culprit fought. Let's consider the culprit's next actions.

column5:
洞窟の入口方向には、メイの
他に朝霧夫婦がいたため、見つから
ずに逃げる事は不可能‥。
column6: Apart from you, May, the Asagiris were at the entrance to the cave, so there's no way the culprit could run away without being noticed...

column5:
となると、どこかに隠れてい
た可能性が強いな。
column6: That being so, there's a strong probability they hid somewhere.

column5:
犯人が隠れたと思われる地点
で、\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押してください。\n
\c<$0B>６０秒以内\c<$0F>にお願いしますよ。
column6: Press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F> at the location where you think the killer hid. Please do it \c<$0B>within 60 seconds\c<$0F>.

column5:
武藤さんを刺した後、犯人は
泉に潜って隠れたと思われます。
column6: We think that after stabbing Mutou, the culprit dove into the spring and hid.

column5:
しかし、泉からあがった跡が
ありませんでした。
column6: But there was no sign that they emerged from the water.

column5:
泉に潜った後、犯人がどの様
に逃げたのかを考えましょう。
column6: Let's consider how the culprit could have escaped after diving into the spring.

column5:
泉に隠れていた犯人が、どこ
から、どうやって逃げ出したか‥？
column6: Having hidden in the spring, where and how did the culprit escape...?

column5:
証拠を見つけないと、泉に隠
れたという仮説もなりたちません。
column6: If we don't find proof, our supposition that they hid in the spring won't hold.

column5:
\c<$0B>６０秒以内\c<$0F>に、探し出して下
さいね。
column6: Find it \c<$0B>within 60 seconds\c<$0F>.

column5:
剥がれた夜光ゴケに、壁に残
された血痕。
column6: Peeled-off moss, and bloodstains left on the wall.

column5:
血痕も、まだ新しいものです
し‥たぶん間違いないでしょう。
column6: The bloodstains are still fresh...I don't think there can be any doubt.
column7: NOTE: "maybe there probably can be no mistaking it" -- japanese is wonderful sometimes!

column5:
距離的には、あまり離れてな
いね。
column6: As far as the distance goes, it's pretty close.

column5:
犯人と格闘していた武藤さん
は、この位置で腹部を刺されて‥、
倒れた。
column6: Mutou, who'd grappled with the culprit, was stabbed in the stomach on this spot...and collapsed.

column5:
その後で、犯人がどこに逃げ
たかだ。
column6: Where did the culprit run off to after that?

column5:
メイや朝霧夫妻が、犯人を見
ていないという事は、どこかに隠れ
ていたと思われるが‥。
column6: The fact that you and the Asagiris didn't see them could mean they hid somewhere, but...

column5:
では、次に犯人が\c<$0C>隠れた地点\c<$0F>
を考えましょう。\n
\c<$0B>犯人の行動\c<$0F>を実行して下さいね。
column6: Then next, let's consider the culprit's \c<$0C>hiding spot\c<$0F>. Use the \c<$0B>Culprit's Actions\c<$0F> command.

column5:
この場所ですか?!\n
‥争いの形跡は、見あたりませんけ
ど。
column6:
This place!?\n
...But there's no sign of a struggle to be found.

column5:
もう少し周囲を調べてから、
また挑戦してみましょう。
column6: Try again after investigating the surroundings some more.

column5:
まだ、よく分かりませんね。
もう少し周囲を調べてから、また挑
戦してみましょう。
column6:
So you don't really know yet?\n
Try again after investigating the surroundings some more.

column5: まさか?!この泉に‥‥？
column6: Could it be!? In this spring...?

column5:
なるほどな。\n
暗い洞窟の中ならば、水の中は絶好
の隠れ場所にもなるか。
column6:
I get it.\n
In a dark cave, the water would make an ideal hiding place, huh.

column5: で‥でもですよ。
column6: B...but...

column5:
泉に隠れたなら、犯人はずぶ
濡れのはずですよね。
column6: If they hid in the spring, wouldn't the culprit get soaking wet?

column5:
だから、泉からあがった地点
の地面が濡れてるはずです。
column6: So, wherever they got out of the spring should be wet as well.

column5:
だけど、この辺りには、そん
な場所なんて見あたりませんよ。
column6: But there's not a place like that to be seen around here.

column5:
まだ泉の中に隠れているわけ
でもないだろうしな。
column6: And there's no way they're still in the spring.

column5:
犯人が、どうやって逃げたの
かを確かめないといけませんね。
column6: We need to ascertain what the culprit did to escape.

column5:
犯人の\c<$0C>逃亡した地点\c<$0F>を探しま
しょう。\n
\c<$0B>犯人の行動\c<$0F>を実行して下さいね。
column6: Search for \c<$0C>the place where the culprit escaped\c<$0F>. Use the \c<$0B>Culprit's Actions\c<$0F> command.

column5:
‥隠れられるような場所とも
思えませんよ、ここ。
column6: ...I don't think this is the kind of place they'd have been able to hide.

column5:
もう少し周囲を調べてから、
また挑戦してみましょう。
column6: Try again after investigating the surroundings some more.

column5: ‥‥地面が濡れてるな。
column6: ...The ground's wet.

column5:
なぁるほど。\n
泉が地下でつながってるわけですね
column6: Oh, I get it. The springs are connected underground, aren't they?

column5:
犯人は、こちら側の泉まで泳
いできて、この場所で泉からあがっ
た。
column6: The culprit swam over to the spring that's on this side and got out of the water here.

column5:
そして、夜光洞から人がいな
くなるのを待って、外へ逃げ出した
んだろう。
column6: Then, they waited until the Noctilucent Cave was deserted and escaped outside.

column5:
ふぅ‥犯人は、かなり児島の
地理に詳しいとみえるな。
column6: Whew...It looks like the culprit had a pretty good grasp of Kojima's geography.

column5:
ともかく、これだけ分かれば
十分だ。
column6: Anyway, we've learned enough here.

column5:
被害者と素子に争った跡がな
い事。
column6: There's not a trace of a struggle between the victim and Motoko.

column5:
そして犯人と思われる人物の
行動が判明した事から、素子を不当
に拘留する理由はない。
column6: And from what we've established about the actions of the person we think's the culprit, there's no reason to keep Motoko in custody.

column5:
この島の駐在に話をつけて、
素子を釈放してやろう。\n
さぁ、行くぞ。
column6: We should settle things with the island's officer and get Motoko released. C'mon, let's go.

column5:
これといって注目するような
ものはありませんよ。
column6: There's nothing that looks like it's worth paying attention to here.

column5:
もう少し周囲を調べてから、
また挑戦してみましょう。
column6: Try again after investigating the surroundings some more.

column5:
そうか‥。立花さん、ここの
ロープが濡れてたって言ってたよね
column6: That's right...Mr. Tachibana, you said the rope here was wet, didn't you?

column5:
ああ、メイが思ってるとおり
だろうよ。
column6: Yeah, it's probably what you're thinking, May.

column5:
これで、ずぶ濡れの犯人が逃
げた事を証明する材料が、また１つ
増えたわけだ。
column6: We've got one more piece of evidence here to prove that the culprit ran away dripping wet.

column5:
渡部さんは、いない様子です
ねぇ。
column6: It looks like Mr. Watabe isn't here.

column5: 困ったなぁ‥‥。
column6: Shoot...

column5: 鍵がかかってますが。
column6: It's locked.

column5:
壊すわけにもいかんしな。\n
どこに行ったかしらんが、駐在を探
すしかあるまい。
column6: We can't go busting it down. Dunno where he's gone, but we'll just have to look for the officer.

column5: メイ！
column6: May!

column5:
もう大丈夫だよ。\n
素子の無実は証明できたから、すぐ
に出してあげる。
column6: It's all right now. We've proved you're innocent, so we'll have you out in no time.

column5:
渡部さんに話をしてくるまで
あと少しだけガマンしてて！
column6: We'll go talk to Mr. Watabe in just a little bit, so hang in there!

[br3]
{[2x]\s<$01>Inspector Watabe!?[1x]
column7: NOTE: translation can't fit on one line, moving to second

column5:
た、立花くんか！\n
いや、久しぶりじゃのぉ。
column6:
T-Tachibana!?\n
Ohh, it's been an era!

column5:
さ、そんな所におらんで、こ
ちらへ座りなさい。
column6: D-don't just stand around[nbsp]-- come sit over here.

column5:
いや、それにしても驚いたわ
い。まさか、こんな所で立花くんに
会うとはなぁ。
column6: Oh, but did you give me a good startle! I'd never've thought[nbsp]-- bumping into you somewhere like this, Tachibana...

column5: 知り合いだったの？
column6: You know each other?

column5:
おれの上司だった方だよ。\n
おれも、草薙も、渡部さんから刑事
のイロハをたたき込まれたんだ。
column6:
He was my boss.\n
Me and Kusanagi both had the ABCs of detective work drilled into us by Watabe.

column5:
‥‥７年前に、武藤が死んで
しまうまではな。
column6: ...Until seven years ago, when Mutou died.

column5:
‥‥‥昔の話じゃよ。\n
無茶な命令で部下を死なせた責任は
大きい‥。
column6: ...It was a long time ago. The responsibility for giving senseless orders and sending a subordinate to his death is grave...

column5:
わしには、人里離れた児島で
暮らすのが似合いなんじゃ‥‥‥。
column6: Living here on remote Kojima fits me...

column5:
ところで、わしに用があった
んじゃないかの？
column6: By the by, didja need something from me?

column5:
さ、榊くんに捜査を手伝って
もらおうと思ったんじゃよ。
column6: Well...I thought I'd get Sakaki to lend a hand with the investigation.
column7: NOTE: the "sa" at the start of this sentence could be taken as a nervous stutter of "Sakaki" (who is of course actually here due to their relationship in the syndicate, so Watabe has reason to feel guilty), or simply as a common speech filler

column5:
無線機が壊されてしもうたん
で、明日までは外に連絡もできんか
らの。
column6: With the radio busted and all, we got no way to contact the outside till tomorrow.

column5:
なんと！‥お前さんが草薙の
娘じゃったと?!\n
なんとも不思議な偶然じゃのぉ‥。
column6: Gracious!...You're Kusanagi's girl!? That's one darned queer coincidence...

column5:
草薙くんが亡くなった事は‥
風の便りで聞いておった。
column6: Kusanagi's passing...I heard about it through the grapevine.

column5:
‥‥いい刑事じゃったのに、
気の毒にのぉ。
column6: ...He was a good detective. Such a pity...

column5:
被害者の青年の事じゃろ？\n
彼の名前は村野じゃが‥。
column6: The young man who was the victim? But his name's Murano...

column5:
さしでがましいようですが、
現場を調べさせてもらいました。\n
被害者の身元も判明しております。
column6: Perhaps it's forward of me, but I got her to let me investigate the crime scene. I've established the victim's identity.

column5:
被害者の名前は武藤孝弘。‥
‥７年前に殉職した、武藤刑事の息
子です。
column6: The victim's name was Takahiro Mutou. ...The son of Detective Mutou, who was killed in the line of duty seven years ago.
...Why...would he...?

column5: 分かりません。
column6: I don't know.

column5:
なぜ児島にいたのか？\n
なぜ殺されたのか？\n
全ての理由が不明です。
column6:
What was he doing on Kojima?\n
Why was he killed?\n
The reasons are all unknown.

column5:
明日、大島に渡って彼の足取
りを調べてみますよ。
column6: Tomorrow, I'll go over to Ohshima and try investigating his movements.

column5:
何か手がかりが見つかるかも
しれません。
column6: I may turn up some kind of clue.

column5:
明日、大島に渡って武藤くん
の人間関係を洗ってみますよ。
column6: Tomorrow, I'll go over to Ohshima and try looking into Mutou's personal relationships.

column5: そうじゃな‥そうしてくれ。
column6: I see...Do that, if you would.

column5:
それで、素子の事なんですけ
ど‥。
column6: So, about Motoko...

column5:
という訳でしてね。\n
犯人は、泉を泳いで逃亡したと思わ
れます。
column6:
So that's how it is.\n
We think the culprit swam through the spring and escaped.

column5:
なるほどのぉ‥ならば、素子
くんを拘留する理由はないの。\n
よし、駐在所へ向かうとするかの。
column6: I getcha...Then I've no reason to keep Miss Motoko in custody. All right, how's about I head to the substation?

column5:
どうやら、そちらの刑事さんが
おられれば、大丈夫な様子でござい
ますね。
column6: With that detective here, it seems that perhaps all will turn out well.

column5:
それでは、私は失礼させていた
だきます。
column6: Well then, I will beg your pardon and take my leave.

column5:
捜査のお手伝いは出来そうにご
ざいませんが、また何かございまし
たら、お申しつけ下さい。
column6: It seems I will be unable to facilitate the investigation, but should anything arise in future, please speak to me.

column5:
‥村野くんが、あの武藤の子
供じゃったとはのぉ‥‥‥。
column6: ...So young Murano was Mutou's boy...

column5:
なるほどのぉ。\n
確かに濡れておるわい。
column6: I see. It's wet, no denying it.

column5:
犯人は、わし達がいなくなる
のを待って、ここから逃亡したわけ
じゃな。
column6: So the culprit waited till we were gone, then escaped through here.

column5:
ここで村野くんと犯人が争っ
たわけじゃな。\n
‥なるほど、血痕も残されておるわ
column6: So, young Murano and the culprit tussled here. ...I getcha. There's bloodstains been left too.

column5:
ちょっと待ってなされ。\n
今、開けてやるでの。
column6:
Hang on just a wee bit.\n
I'm openin' it up.

column5:
も、素子?!\n
‥‥‥もう、大丈夫だよ。
column6:
M-Motoko!?\n
...It's okay now.

column5:
二人とも、本当にすまんかっ
たの。
column6: The pair of you, I'm sorry's as can be for this.

column5:
今日はホテルに戻って、ゆっ
くり休みなされ。
column6: Go back to the hotel for tonight and have yourselves a rest.

column5:
素子！\n
渡部さんを連れてきたよ。\n
すぐに出してあげるからね！
column6:
Motoko!\n
I've brought Mr. Watabe. He'll let you out in just a second!

column5: 順を追って説明しますね。
column6: I'll explain in order.

column5:
１：書き込む\c<$0C>地名\c<$0F>を指すように、\c<$0B>十
字キー\c<$0F>で羽根を動かし、\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を
押します。
column6: 1: Use the \c<$0B>D-Pad\c<$0F> to move the feather so it points to the \c<$0C>place name\c<$0F> to fill in, and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
２：書き込む\c<$0C>場所\c<$0F>を指すように、\c<$0B>十
字キー\c<$0F>で地図上の羽根を動かして、\c<$0B>
[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押します。
column6: 2: Use the \c<$0B>D-Pad\c<$0F> to move the feather so it points to the \c<$0C>area\c<$0F> to fill in, and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
３：書き込みを\c<$0C>中止\c<$0F>する時は、\c<$0B>終了\c<$0F>
に羽根を合わせて\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押すか\c<$0B>
[II]ボタン\c<$0F>を押して下さい。
column6: 3: To \c<$0C>stop\c<$0F> filling in, move the feather to \c<$0B>Done\c<$0F> and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>, or press the \c<$0B>II Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
画面の下に表示される地名の
色は、次のような意味を持っていま
す。
column6: The place names displayed at the bottom of the screen have the following meanings.

column5: \c<$09>黄色\c<$0F>‥地名を書き込んでいない。
column6: \c<$09>Yellow:\c<$0F> You haven't filled in the place name.

column5:
\c<$08>緑色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ後。\n
正しいか否かが確認できていない。
column6: \c<$08>Green:\c<$0F> Filled in. Whether it's correct or not is unconfirmed.

column5:
\c<$0A>赤色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ場所が、間違って
いる。
column6: \c<$0A>Red:\c<$0F> The location you filled in is incorrect.

column5: \c<$0F>白色\c<$0F>‥書き込んだ場所が正しかった
column6: \c<$0F>White:\c<$0F> The location you filled in was correct.

column5:
外に出た時に、ナビが地図を
表示します。
column6: When you leave, Navi will display the map.

column5:
画面上の羽根を、行きたい場
所にあわせて、\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>を押してく
ださい。
column6: Move the on-screen feather to the place you want to go and press the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
四角形の\c<$0C>１辺は５００メート
ル\c<$0F>です。
column6: \c<$0C>One square\c<$0F> on the grid is \c<$0C>500 meters\c<$0F>.

column5:
柳　素子　（やなぎ　もとこ）\n
まさか、素子が人殺し?!\n
そんなはずないよっ！
column6:
Motoko Yanagi\n
No way[nbsp]-- Motoko, a murderer!?\n
That's impossible!

column5:
柳　素子　（やなぎ　もとこ）\n
一時はどうなる事かと思ったけど、
疑いも晴らせて、本当によかったよ
column6:
Motoko Yanagi\n
I wasn't sure what was going to happen for a minute there. Thank goodness we got her cleared of suspicion.

column5:
立花　次郎　（たちばな　じろう）
刑事さん。実は綾華のお父さんだっ
たんだよね‥。
column6:
Jirou Tachibana\n
A police detective. So he was actually Ayaka's father...

column5:
朝霧　正臣　（あさぎり　まさみ）
温子さんの夫。新婚旅行で２つもの
事件に巻き込まれた不運の人。
column6:
Masami Aasagiri\n
Atsuko's husband. An unlucky man who's gotten caught up in two incidents on his honeymoon.

column5:
朝霧　温子　（あさぎり　あつこ）
正臣さんの奥さん。せっかくの新婚
旅行だったのに‥不幸な人だよね。
column6:
Atsuko Asagiri\n
Masami's wife. She'd finally gotten to go on her honeymoon, but now...What an unfortunate woman.

column5:
木原　尚子　（きはら　なおこ）\n
ハ虫類研究者。児島にいる珍種のヘ
ビを捕まえるのが目的なんだって。
column6:
Naoko Kihara\n
A reptile researcher. Says her goal is to capture rare snake species that are on Kojima.

column5:
渡部　吟次　（わたべ　ぎんじ）\n
児島の駐在さん。人当りのいい温厚
そうなおじいさん。
column6:
Ginji Watabe\n
Kojima's resident officer. Seems like an affable, mild-mannered old man.

column5:
老婆\n
鎌を振り回す、謎のお婆さん。あま
りお近付きにはなりたくないなぁ。
column6:
Old Woman\n
A mysterious old woman brandishing a sickle. I'd rather not get too close to her...

column5:
青年\n
名前は村野さん。ちょっと無愛想で
感じがいいとは言えないなぁ。
column6:
Young Man\n
His name is Murano. He's a bit brusque, and I can't say he gives off a pleasant mood.

column5:
武藤　孝弘　（むとう　たかひろ）
被害者。立花さんの亡くなられた同
僚の、息子さんだったんだって。
column6:
Takahiro Mutou\n
The victim. Apparently, he was the son of Mr. Tachibana's deceased colleague.

column5:
榊　弘司　（さかき　こうじ）\n
児島ホテルのオーナー。\n
礼儀正しい紳士さん。
column6:
Kouji Sakaki\n
The owner of the Kojima Hotel.\n
A well-mannered gentleman.

column5:
てんぐいわ）\n
花コウ岩でできた巨岩塔。
column6:
Tengu Rock\n
An enormous rock tower made of granite.

column5:
海上からの高さは、１１．４ｍにも
達します。
column6: It extends 11.4 meters above sea level.

column5:
その昔、児島の天狗と大島の天狗が
力を競い合った時に、児島天狗が投
げた岩であると伝えられています。
岬の先端から、眺めることができま
す。
column6:
Legend tells that in ancient times, when the tengu of Kojima had a contest of might with the tengu of Ohshima, the Kojima tengu threw this rock.
[wait][clear]

You can look out upon it from the tip of the cape.

column5: ‥こっちは裏ですって。
column6: ...Hey, this is the back.

column5:
やこうどう）\n
夜光ゴケが自生する洞窟です。
column6:
Noctilucent Cave\n
A cave where noctilucent moss grows natively.

column5:
夜光ゴケはセン類に属するコケ植物
であり、発光する性質を持っている
珍しい植物です。
column6: Noctilucent moss is a bryophyte with the unusual property of emitting light.

column5:
発光のために微量元素を必要とする
ため、自生域は限られています。
column6: Because it requires micronutrients for the emission of light, its native range is limited.

column5:
夜光洞では、洞窟の奥に備えられた
スイッチで照明を消すことができま
す。
column6: In Noctilucent Cave, you can turn off the lights using the switch installed within the cave.

column5:
夜光ゴケと岩石に含まれる鉱物が闇
に放つ光が、幻想的な世界をつくり
あげます。
column6: The light given off by the noctilucent moss and the minerals in the rocks creates a fantastic world.

column5:
←照明用スイッチ\n
消した後は、必ずつけるようにして
ください。
column6:
[<-] Light Switch\n
After turning off, please be sure to turn back on.

column5:
へぇ、こんな所に浜辺があっ
たんだ。
column6: Ooh...So there's a beach somewhere like this.

column5:
周囲が岩場に囲まれてますか
ら、ちょっと見ただけでは分かりま
せんね。
column6: The surrounding area is enclosed by rocks, so you wouldn't know it at a glance.

column5:
この岩場の向こうが、港だよ
ね？
column6: So the harbor's on the other side of these rocks?

column5:
そうですよ。\n
‥とは言っても、この険しい岩場の
５００メートル先ですけどね。
column6:
That's right.\n
...Though it's 500 meters away over steep rock.

column5:
ロープですか？\n
海から流れ着いたんでしょうか。
column6:
Is that a rope?\n
Maybe it washed in from the sea.

column5:
ロープの端が岩場に結び付け
られてるからね。\n
誰かが結んだのは間違いないよ。
column6: The rope's end is attached to the rocks. Someone definitely tied it there.

column5:
ま、たいして意味はないだろ
うけどね。
column6: Oh well, I doubt there's really any significance to it.

column5:
ご用がございましたら
承ります。
column6: Should you need anything, I'll be right with you.

column5:
何か、ご用でございま
しょうか？
column6: Is there something I can help you with?

column5:
\n
　　　　　ＣＬＯＳＥ
column6:
\n

CLOSED
#DISABLEPADANDCENTER()

column5:
とりあえず、素子の様子を見
てきた方がいいかな。
column6: For now, maybe we should go see how Motoko is doing.

column5:
昨日の事は、結構こたえてい
たみたいでしたからねぇ。
column6: Yes, yesterday's events seemed to have taken quite a toll on her.

column5: お？‥忘れてた。
column6: Oh?...I forgot.

column5:
大切な証拠品とか言いながら
結局、ボクが持ってきちゃったんだ
よね。
column6: For all that talk about it being important evidence, in the end, I took it with me.

column5: お‥おおっとぉ！
column6: Wh...whoops!

column5: 柄のフタが外れたんですか？
column6: The handle's cover came off?

column5:
そうみたい。\n
中が空洞になってて‥紙が入ってる
よ。
column6:
Looks like it.\n
The inside's hollow...and there's a paper in it.

column7:
NOTE: the letter's content is shown in an image here but not presented in the dialogue in full yet. i've dumped this line in such a way as to allow an extra box to be added at the start with the translation.

letter's content (as given in later dialogue): 三本岬の断崖。倉庫。

column6: Well, hmm...?

column5: 素子、いないのかな？
column6: Is Motoko not here?

column5:
ま、まさか、自殺してたりし
て‥‥。
column6: C-could she have committed suicide...?

column5:
縁起でもない事、言わないで
よ!!
column6: Don't say something so ominous!

column5: まだ寝てるのかなぁ？
column6: Are they still asleep?

column5: 昨日は大変でしたからねぇ‥
column6: Yesterday was hard on them, huh...

三本岬のこと　　倉庫のこと\n
立ち去る

column5:
聞き及んでおりますわ
昨日は、とても大変でしたとか。
column6:
I heard about it.\n
Yesterday was truly awful.

column5:
それが‥凶器でしたの
ね。
column6: That was...the murder weapon, was it?

column5:
私には、見覚えがござ
いませんが‥‥。\n
お力になれなくて申し訳ありません
column6: I have no recollection of it...Forgive me if I'm of no help here.

column5:
三本岬？\n
‥‥何の事でございましょう？
column6:
Threewood Cape?\n
...What might you mean by that?

column5:
それに断崖と申されま
しても‥この島のほとんどの海岸が
断崖になっておりますが。
column6: And though you ask me about a bluff...almost all of this island's shores are bluffs.

column5:
まさか‥当ホテルの倉
庫の事ではございませんでしょう？
column6: Could you be referring to...our hotel's storehouse?

column5:
児島の海は、大変きれ
いですよ。
column6: Kojima's sea is extraordinarily pretty.

column5:
西側の海岸が、浜辺に
なってますから、おいでになっては
いかがでしょう。
column6: The western side is beach, so why don't you try going there?

column5:
本日の朝、榊から聞い
ております。
column6: I heard about it from Sakaki this morning.
column7: NOTE: the lack of honorific with "sakaki" here is interesting -- is this guy secretly in with the gang and we just never find out? it's a mystery for the ages

column5:
現在調査中である為、
無意味に騒ぎ立てるなと、言われて
おりますが。
column6: He said that since the investigation is currently ongoing, we'd better not raise a pointless fuss.

column5:
一見すれば、普通の鎌
にしか見えませんね。
column6: At a glance, that seems to just be an ordinary sickle.

column5:
三本岬‥で、ございま
すか？\n
いえ、私は存じておりません。
column6:
Threewood Cape...you say?\n
No, I don't know of that.

column5:
倉庫‥？\n
一体、何の倉庫でしょうか。
column6:
Warehouse...?\n
What warehouse do you mean?

column5:
児島の西岸は、絶好の
海水浴場でございます。\n
きれいな浜辺が続いていますよ。
column6: Kojima's west coast is an ideal swimming spot. The clean shore stretches on.

column5: あら。おはよう、メイ。
column6: Oh, my. Good morning, May.

column5:
お・は・よ！\n
‥‥元気そうでなによりだね。
column6:
Well, good MORNING!\n
...You're looking perkier than ever.
column7: NOTE: i think the "ohayo" here is meant to be a bit sarcastic/reproachful to go along with may's complaint about being left behind

column5:
で、ボクをほっておいて二人
で、お食事？\n
それって‥ヒドクない？
column6: But you ignored me and went off to eat by yourselves? Isn't that a little...you know, rude?

column5:
ちゃんと呼びに行ったわよ。
でも、起きなかったんだもの。
column6: I went over to call you and everything. But hey, you didn't wake up.

column5:
そのくらいにしておいて、メ
イも座れ。\n
今日の事を話そうじゃないか。
column6:
That's enough of that.\n
Sit down, May. How about we talk about what's going on today?

column5:
‥‥というわけでね。鎌の中
に、こんな紙が入ってたワケ。
column6: ...so, that's the story. This piece of paper was inside the sickle.

column5:
『三本岬の断崖。倉庫。』‥
古風な手だな。\n
通信筒がわりに使っていたんだろう
column6: `Bluff on Threewood Cape. Warehouse.~ ...It's in old-fashioned handwriting. This was probably used as a message tube.

column5:
通信筒？\n
あの青年が、誰かと連絡を取るため
に利用してたって事？
column6:
Message tube?\n
Then that man was using it to communicate with someone?

column5: まず間違いないだろうな。
column6: In all likelihood.

column5:
ま、いい。おれと素子は、こ
れから大島に行って、被害者の事を
洗いざらい調べてくる。
column6: Well, whatever. Me and Motoko are going to go to Ohshima and take a comprehensive look into the victim.

column5:
これの調査は、メイにまかせ
よう。
column6: I'm leaving the investigation here in your hands, May.

column5:
今回は、警察には任せられな
い事情があってな。\n
すまんが協力してもらうぞ。
column6: There's circumstances this time that mean we can't leave it up to the police. Sorry, but I'll have to get you to help out.

column5:
おれ達が戻ってくるまでに、
危険でない範囲内で、調べておいて
くれ。
column6: Until we get back, limit yourself to investigating things that aren't dangerous.

column5:
暗くなる前には戻るつもりだ
可能なだけ、調べをつけておいてく
れ。
column6: I'm planning to get back before dark. Keep up the investigation as best you can.

column5:
デートよ、デート！\n
うらやましいでしょ。
column6:
It's a date[nbsp]-- a date!\n
Jealous, huh?

column5:
あんたねぇ‥、立花さんは綾
華のお父さんだよ。
column6: Why, you...Mr. Tachibana is Ayaka's dad!

column5:
それに‥こき使われるだけだ
と思うけどなぁ。
column6: Besides...I'm pretty sure you're just going to get pushed around.

column5:
どうして命を落とす事になった
のか‥。あの青年には、本当に‥お
気の毒なことでした。
column6: Why did a life have to be lost...? What a true pity for that young man...

column5:
一刻も早く、犯人が見
つかるといいのですが‥。
column6: I hope the culprit will be found as soon as possible, but...

column5:
仏さんを、暗い洞窟に置きっ
ぱなしにする訳にもいかんからな。
大島の警察に話をつけてくるのさ。
column6: We can't leave the deceased lying around in a dark cave. I'll make the arrangements with the Ohshima police.

column5:
‥警察は、アテに出来ないん
じゃなかったっけ？
column6: But I thought we weren't going to be able to rely on the police?

column5:
少数だが信頼できる奴もいる
それに、ごまかし方なら心得ている
さ。
column6: It's not many, but there's a few guys I can trust. 'Sides, I know how to play the game of deception.

column5:
他人の心配する前に、あまり
危険な事をするんじゃないぞ。
column6: Before you start worrying about other people, make sure you're keeping away from danger yourself!

column5:
こ、殺されちゃった人には、
わ、悪いんだけど‥。
column6: Th-this is mean to the man that died, b-but...

column5:
ま、まさか死体と一緒に船に
乗るとは、お、思わなかったわね。
column6: I-I never thought we'd be riding in a boat with a c-corpse...

column5:
おいこら!!\n
仏さんに、悪さをしちゃいかん！
column6:
Hey, quiddit!\n
Don'tcha go desecratin' the dead!

column5:
それにしても、気の毒なこっ
たなぁ。
column6: Ah, man, 's a damn shame.

column5:
まだ若いのに、何で殺されち
まったのかねぇ。
column6: Why'd he hafta get done in so young?

column5:
さて、もうすぐ出港するぞ。
さ、嬢ちゃんは乗らねぇんだろ。\n
だったら降りた降りた！
column6: Well, we're settin' out soon. Missy, you ain't ridin', are ya? Then giddout!

column5:
こ、これは失礼致しました。\n
私めに、何かご用でございましょう
か。
column6:
I-I beg your pardon.\n
Have you some business with me?

column5:
私めに、ご用でございましょう
か。
column6: Have you some business with me?

column5:
この島で、あの様な事件が起き
るとは‥。\n
本当に、残念でございます。
column6: For such an incident to occur on this island...It's truly most regrettable.

column5:
申し訳ございませんが、私には
分かりかねます。
column6: I'm terribly sorry, but I fear I know nothing about that.

column5:
ふぅむ‥いや、聞いたことがあ
りませんね。\n
お力になれなくて申し訳ありません
column6: Hmm...No, I can't say I've heard of that. My apologies that I can't be of use.

column5:
倉庫‥ですか？\n
‥‥いや、申し訳ありませんが、思
い当たりませんね。
column6:
A...warehouse?\n
...No, I'm most sorry, but I'm afraid that doesn't bring anything to mind.

column5:
西岸が浜辺になっております。
海水浴を楽しまれるのも、よいかと
存じますが。
column6: The west coast is beach. Perhaps it might be a good idea to enjoy a dip in the ocean.

column5:
いや、今回の様な事件
は始めてですよ。
column6: Ah, this is the first time we've had an incident of this sort.

column5:
おかげで、支配人もピ
リピリしてましてね。
column6: Because of that, the manager's on edge as much as anyone.

column5:
気にしすぎでしょうけ
ど、何となく島全体の雰囲気が暗い
んですよ。
column6: Perhaps I'm worrying too much, but somehow, I feel like the island's whole aura has darkened.

column5:
柄に細工がしてあるん
ですか？\n
珍しいものですねぇ。
column6: There's a trick to the handle, is there? How unusual.

column5:
三本岬の断崖‥断崖と
言うからには、この島の東岸になる
でしょうね。
column6: A bluff at Threewood Cape...If we're talking about bluffs, I suppose that would be the island's east side.

column5:
しかし、三本岬という
名前は聞いた事がありませんでして
‥申し訳有りません。
column6: But I've never heard the name `Threewood Cape~...My apologies.

column5:
う〜ん、何の事でしょ
うか？\n
ちょっと見当がつきかねますが‥。
column6:
Mmm...What do you mean?\n
I'm afraid I really can't begin to guess...

column5:
\c<$0C>港のすぐ西\c<$0F>の浜辺が穴
場ですよ。
column6: The beach \c<$0C>just west of the harbor\c<$0F> is a hidden gem.

column5:
岩場で囲まれてまして
ちょっと分かりにくい所にあります
けど。
column6: It's surrounded by rocks and a little hard to spot, though.

column5: おや、おはようございます。
column6: Oh, good morning.

column5:
昨日は大変でしたけど、素子
さんが犯人じゃないと聞いて、ほっ
としましたよ。
column6: Yesterday was awful, but I gave a sigh of relief to hear Motoko wasn't the culprit.

column5:
素子さんが犯人じゃないって
のは、榊支配人から聞いたんです。
column6: I heard from Mr. Sakaki that Motoko isn't the culprit.
column7: NOTE: he refers to Sakaki here with a title that's like "Manager Sakaki" or "Executive Sakaki". there's not really a good way to make it work in English.

column5:
いや、本当にほっとしました
けど‥早く犯人が捕まるといいです
よね。
column6: Ah, I really did sigh in relief, but...I hope they catch the one who did it soon.

column5:
う〜ん‥申し訳ないんですが
それが、どんな手がかりになるのか
は、ぼくにはサッパリですよ。
column6: Mmm...I'm sorry, but I have no idea what kind of clue that might be.

column5:
三本岬‥‥？\n
いや、聞いた事もないですねぇ。
column6:
Threewood Cape...?\n
No, I've never heard of that.

column5:
倉庫って言われても‥。\n
[expr]<$01>そうだ！大島の港にあった、倉庫な
んて違いますかね？
column6: A warehouse...no, I don't think...[expr]<$01>Oh, right! There was some kind of warehouse at the harbor in Ohshima, wasn't there?

column5:
ああ‥昨日、妻と一緒に行っ
てきたんですけどね。
column6: Right...I went there yesterday with my wife.
column7: NOTE: extra conversation if you didn't hear about the beach from them in the lobby near the start of the case

column5:
確かにきれいでしたけど‥、
そんなに感動するものなんでしょう
かねぇ。
column6: It was certainly pretty, but...well, was it really quite THAT grand?

column5:
正直、妻とはいえ女性の感性
には、とまどってしまいますよ。
column6: Honestly, women's sensibilities perplex me[nbsp]-- even my wife's.

column5: あ‥おはようございます。
column6: Ah...Good morning.

column5:
昨日は‥申し訳ありませんで
した。\n
その‥素子さんを疑ったりして‥。
column6: I'm very sorry about...yesterday. I mean...suspecting Motoko and all that...

column5:
正直‥あの事は、よく覚えて
ないんです。
column6: Honestly...I don't remember it very well.

column5:
でも、素子さんが犯人じゃな
いって分かって、本当によかったで
すわ。
column6: But it's so wonderful that you've found out that Motoko isn't the culprit.

column5:
たしか‥児島に着いたときに
変なお婆さんがいましたよね。
column6: If I recall correctly...when we arrived at Kojima, there was a strange old woman.

column5:
あの人が持っていた鎌に見え
るんですけど‥？
column6: That seems like the sickle she was holding...?

column5:
三本‥岬？\n
岬が３つ並んでる‥なんて事ないで
すよね。すみません。
column6:
Threewood...Cape?\n
A cape with three kinds of trees on it?...But there's nothing like that, is there? Sorry.
column7: NOTE: the japanese name for this cape is vague -- the literal meaning is like "cape of three long and cylindrical things" -- and could be interpreted as indicating "three capes", which is what atsuko does in japanese here. this can't really be localized directly.

column5:
ごめんなさい‥。\n
ぜんぜん知らないんです。
column6: I'm sorry...I don't know anything about that.

column5:
昨日ホテルに来る前に、夫と
泳いできたんです。
column6: Before we came to the hotel yesterday, I went swimming there with my husband.
column7: NOTE: if you didn't talk to the asagiris about this in the hotel lobby near the start of the case, you can ask about the beach here and get this conversation

column5:
岩場に囲まれているから分か
りにくいかも知れないけど、\c<$0C>港の側\c<$0F>
にあるんです。
column6: It may be a bit difficult to spot because it's surrounded by rocks, but it's \c<$0C>to the side of the harbor\c<$0F>.

column5:
ゴミなんか全然なくて‥本当
に、きれいな浜辺なんですよ。
column6: There's not a bit of garbage...It's a truly beautiful beach.

column5:
昨日の、お詫びという訳でも
ないんですけど‥。\n
後で\c<$0C>浜辺\c<$0F>に行きませんか？
column6: I know it's no apology for yesterday, but...would you like to go to the \c<$0C>beach\c<$0F> later?
column7: NOTE: if you completely ignored the asagiris in the hotel lobby near the start of the case, and thus never learned about the beach, you get this extra conversation when talking to atsuko in the restaurant to make sure you know about it

column5:
昨日、きれいな浜辺を見つけ
ましたの。ご案内しますわ。
column6: We found a beautiful beach yesterday. I'll show you to it.

column5:
[2x]\s<$01>ひぁっ!![1x]\s<$03>\n
\n
な、何ですか！そのヘビはっ?!
column6:
[2x]\s<$01>YAAAH!![1x]\s<$03>[br3]
[br3]
Wh-what!? What's that snake--!?

column5:
うふ。\n
さっき捕まえてきたんです。\n
カワイイでしょ？
column6:
Heh-heh.\n
I just caught him a minute ago. Isn't he cute?

column5:
でもねぇ、この島のヘビちゃ
んたちって、気性が荒くて荒くて‥
column6: But the snakies on this island just have the most BRUTISH temperament...

column5:
人を見ると、すぐに襲いかか
ろうとするんだもの。ちょっとビッ
クリしちゃった。
column6: The moment they see someone, they'll rear up and attack. Gave me quite a shock.

column5:
そ、そんな物騒なヘビを見せ
ないで下さいっ!!
column6: P-please, don't show me such dangerous snakes!

column5: カワイイのにぃ‥‥。
column6: But he's so cute...

column5:
一人で泳いだって楽しくない
もんね‥‥。
column6: It wouldn't be any fun swimming by myself...

column5:
はぁ‥こんな所まで来て事件
の調査だなんて‥ツいてないなぁ。
column6: (sigh)...Coming all the way out here to investigate the case...I'm having no luck, am I?
column7:
CHECK
NOTE: immediately follows the previous line if tachibana and motoko have left

column6: [3x]\s<$01>GIVE IT BACK![1x]
column7:
NOTE: okay, so this is a situation that really can't be translated properly.

the old woman here repeatedly screams "kaese", meaning "give [something] back [to me]". the scenario so far is designed to lead the player to believe that she's demanding her sickle back -- "Give it back!"

the twist is that we later find out that the old woman is the grandmother of Mutou, the victim. she's actually rhetorically demanding her grandson's life back from Watabe -- "Give him back!"

it's simply not possible to recreate this ambiguity in english to the same degree as the original. any direct translation requires a pronoun of some sort. and pretty much every conceivable way of rephrasing it is awkward and/or too long to work well. we'll just have to make do.

column5:
返せっ！返せっ！\n
[2x]\s<$01>返せぇぇっ!!
column6:
Back! BACK![br3]
[2x]\s<$01>BAAAAAAACK![1x]

column5:
わ、\n
[2x]\s<$01>渡部さんっ?!
column6:
M...[br3]
[2x]\s<$01>Mr. Watabe!?[1x]

column5:
今の‥例のお婆さんでしたよ
ね。
column6: That was...that old woman, wasn't it?

column5: ひどい‥‥。
column6: That was awful...

column5:
‥いいんじゃ。\n
婆さんは、悪くない‥‥全てわしが
悪いんじゃ。
column6:
...It's fine.\n
It's not the old woman's fault...it's all my own doing.

column5: ‥当然の報いなんじゃよ‥。
column6: ...It's just my just deserts...

column5:
よいこらしょ‥と。\n
ふえぇ‥ところで、わしに用じゃな
かったかの？
column6:
Well, chin up...there we go.\n
Hoo...By the by, anything I can help ya with?

column5: どうしたかの？
column6: What's the matter?

column5:
事件のこと　　　鎌のこと\n
三本岬のこと　　倉庫のこと\n
老婆のこと　　　立ち去る
column6:
The incident
[sp]<$70>
The sickle
\n

Threewood Cape
[sp]<$70>
Warehouse
\n

The old woman
[sp]<$70>
Leave

column5: イヤな出来事じゃったの‥。
column6: What a bone-chillin' business...

column5:
それは、村野くんの命を奪っ
た凶器じゃな‥。
column6: That's the murder weapon that stole young Murano's life...

column5:
婆さんが駐在所に投げ込んだ
やつじゃが‥彼女は犯人ではないよ
column6: It's the one the old woman threw into the substation...but let me tell you, she's not the culprit.

column5:
‥‥‥‥‥‥‥‥島の者は、
誰も知らんじゃろうな。\n
危険な場所で、誰も寄りつかん。
column6: ...None of the island's people know 'bout it. It's a dangerous place nobody goes to.

column5:
崖っぷちに３本の木が、ねじ
れるように絡まって立っておっての
それが、名前の由来なんじゃ。
column6: There's three trees standing there that's grown together all twisty-like. That's where the name's come from.

column5: \c<$0C>島の最北端\c<$0F>の海岸の事じゃよ
column6: It's the shore of \c<$0C>the island's northmost tip\c<$0F>.

column5: 場所が分からんかったかの？
column6: Didn't get where it is?

column5:
三本岬は、児島の\c<$0C>最北端\c<$0F>の海
岸の事じゃよ。
column6: Threewood Cape refers to the shore of \c<$0C>the island's northmost tip\c<$0F>.

column5:
‥‥そうじゃのぉ。\n
‥‥三本岬に倉庫がある、との意味
かのぉ‥。
column6:
...I see.\n
...So it means there's a warehouse at Threewood Cape...

column5:
‥‥‥すまんが‥今は、何も
聞かんでくれんかのぉ‥。
column6: ...Sorry, but...could ya not ask me anything about that just now...?

column5:
もしかして‥ロープを使って
崖を降りようなんて思ってません？
短すぎると思いますよ。
column6: Wait a minute...You're not considering using the rope to climb down the cliff, are you? I think you're overthinking it.

column5:
持っていく\n
持っていかない
column6:
Take it\n
Don't take it

column5:
三本岬ですか‥なるほどです
ねぇ。
column6: Threewood Cape...I see now.

column5:
どうやったら、こんな奇妙な
形に育つんでしょう？
column6: I wonder what happened to make them grow in this bizarre shape?

column5:
倉庫なんて‥見あたらないけ
どなぁ。
column6: Well, I don't see any kind of warehouse around here...

column5:
意外に、崖下にあったりする
んですよね。
column6: It could be something odd like being below the cliff, right?

column5:
‥‥‥あの洞窟の事かなぁ。
ロープでもないと降りられないよ。
column6:
...Does it mean that cave?\n
We can't get down there without a rope.

column5:
メ、メイ！この崖を降りるつ
もりなんですか?!
column6: M-May! Are you thinking of climbing down the cliff!?

column5: ほ、本当に降りるんですか？
column6: A-are you REALLY going to climb down?

column5: ‥‥‥長さが足りませんね。
column6: ...It's not long enough, huh?

column5:
この方法じゃ、ダメか‥。\n
いいアイディアだって思ったんだけ
どなぁ。
column6:
So this way won't work...\n
I thought it was a good idea, though...

column5:
だからやめましょうって言っ
たのに‥。
column6: Hey, listen, I TOLD you not to bother with it...
column7: NOTE: i'm somewhat disappointed they didn't make a game over here for killing yourself trying to climb down the cliff

column5:
よぉ。刑事さんから伝言だぜ
『くれぐれも、無茶をするな』\n
だってよ。
column6: 'Sup. Got a message for ya from the detective. He says `Seriously, don't do anything stupid.~

column5:
ふん。\n
世の中、おかしな奴らばかりだぜ。
column6:
Hmph.\n
Ain't nothin' in this world but kooks.

column5:
好き好んで命を奪おうなんて
考える奴の、気がしれねぇよな。
column6: Guys that go takin' lives just 'cause they wanna[nbsp]-- I got no clue.

column5:
そんな物騒なモンを振り回さ
んでくれよ。
column6: Don't go wavin' around some dangerous thing like that.

column5:
おれの船に傷でもつけたら、
タダじゃ済まんぜ。
column6: You hurt somebody in my boat, you ain't gonna like what happens next.

column5:
三本岬？\n
いや、知らねぇなあ。
column6:
Threewood Cape?\n
Nah, never hearda it.

column5:
ううん。\n
場所は分かってるんだけど、船でも
ないと行けそうにないの。
column6: No, no. I know where it is, but it looks like I won't be able to get there without a boat.

column5:
ああ、そういう事かい。\n
要するに、おれに三本岬とやらに連
れていけって言うんだな。
column6:
Oh, that whatcha mean?\n
So basically, you're askin' me to take ya to this Threewood Cape.

column5:
なんでい。\n
結局、三本岬に行くんかい？
column6: What, we goin' to Threewood Cape after all?

column5:
連れていってもらう\n
やっぱりやめる
column6:
Get him to take you\n
Give up on it after all

column5:
よっしゃ!!\n
それじゃ早速行くとするかいっ！
column6:
ARRIGHT!\n
Then how 'bout we make like a tree!?

column5:
あん？\n
倉庫ぉ？\n
何の事だい？
column6:
Uhm? Warehouse?\n
Whaddya mean?

column5:
ああ、おかしくなっちまった
婆さんの事か。\n
あまり、関わらん方がいいぜ。
column6: Ahh, you mean the crazy old lady. Ya'd do well to stay away from her.

column7: NOTE: actually part of the conversation with tachibana and motoko near the start of the segment. i'm guessing it wasn't originally there and they decided to add it in later to make the conversation flow more nicely.

column5:
ご用がございましたら
承ります。
column6: Should you need anything, I'll be right with you.

column5: は〜い
column6: Coming!

column5: ん〜？どれどれ‥‥。
column6: Hm? Let's see...

column5:
お客様。\n
申し訳ございませんが、この先にお
通しする訳にはまいりません。
column6:
Ma'am.\n
I'm terribly sorry, but coming back here is not permitted.
