column6: Don't save

column5: セーブできませんでした。
column6: Unable to save.

column5: セーブしました。
column6: Saved.

column5: セーブしません。
column6: Will not save.
column7: NOTE: choosing "don't save" at the case end save screen

column5:
\n
あづ
た、立花さん？なんで‥‥。
column6: M-Mr. Tachibana? Why...?

column5:
なんでとは、またゴアイサツ
だな。\n
ま、それはともかく、紹介しよう。
column6:
`Why?~ Fine way to say hello.\n
Ah, whatever. Let me introduce you.

column5:
こちらは、大瀧警視正。\n
さつきヶ丘警察署の署長だ。
column6: This is Senior Inspector Ohtaki. He's the chief of Satsukigaoka Police Station.
column7: NOTE: i'm not familiar with police ranks in english much less japanese, so i had to look this up. Ohtaki's title of 警視正 is usually given as "senior superintendent" or simply "police inspector". for brevity and clarity, i've gone with "senior inspector".

column5:
はは、今日一日はスターさん
が署長だがね。
column6: Ha-ha[nbsp]-- but you're the chief for today, aren't you, Miss Star?

column5:
見る\n
話す
column6:
Look\n
Talk

column5:
周囲　　　　　　立花刑事\n
大瀧警視正　　　見ない
column6:
Surroundings
[sp]<$70>
Detective Tachibana
\n

Inspector Ohtaki
[sp]<$70>
Don't look

column5:
立花刑事\n
大瀧警視正\n
話さない
column6:
Detective Tachibana\n
Inspector Ohtaki\n
Don't talk

column5:
大瀧警視正\n
話さない
column6:
Inspector Ohtaki\n
Don't talk

column5:
この公園で『秋の交通安全式
典』があるんだよね。
column6: The {Autumn Traffic Safety Parade} is going to be in this park.

column5:
表彰されたついでに、一日署
長を務める事になったんだけど‥、
ちょっと堅苦しい仕事だよねぇ。
column6: They decided that while I was being commended, I might as well act as chief of police for the day...but it's kind of a strict job, huh?

column5:
犯人逮捕に貢献して表彰され
た女優なんて、ボクが初めてじゃな
い？
column6: Am I the first actress to get commended for contributing to a criminal's arrest?

column5:
式典は午後３時から。\n
あと３時間もあるけど、準備はほと
んど終ってるみたい。
column6:
The parade starts at 3:00.\n
There's a good three hours left, but it looks like the setup is practically done.

column5:
あの『組織』の事件から、も
う１カ月が経ったんだよね。
column6: It's been a month now since the Syndicate incident.

column5:
立花さんも元気でやってるみ
たいだし。\n
よかったねぇ。
column6: Looks like Mr. Tachibana's been keeping upbeat. That's a good sign.

column5:
声は聞こえないけど、表情が
キツいところを見ると、あまりいい
話じゃないみたいだね。
column6: I can't hear his voice, but going by the tight look on his face, I don't think he likes what he's hearing.

column5:
この人が署長さんなんだ‥。
まぁ、もっとも、今日だけはボクが
署長になるんだけどね。
column6: So this man is the chief...Though I suppose _I'm_ the chief just for today, aren't I?

column5:
それにしても‥なんで、立花
さんがここにいるの？
column6: Anyway...What are you doing here, Mr. Tachibana?

column5:
お前な、自分の親父の職場も
知らなかったのか？
column6: What, you didn't even know where your pops worked?

column5:
おれは、この『さつきヶ丘警
察署』に勤めているんだぜ。\n
無論、お前の親父も一緒だった。
column6: I work here at the Satsukigaoka Police Station. I was with your dad, of course.

column5:
おっと、すまん。\n
電話だ。
column6:
Whoops, sorry.\n
That's my phone.

column5:
制服も、お似合いでしたよ。
ずっとうちの署に勤めてもらいたい
くらいだな。
column6: The uniform suited you, too. It makes me wish you'd keep on working at our station.

column5:
草薙くんは、真に模範的な刑
事だった。\n
実に立派だったよ。
column6: Kusanagi was a truly exemplary detective. A fine man indeed.

column5:
彼が逝ってしまってから、も
う５年になるが‥、彼は今でも我々
の誇りだよ。
column6: It's been five years now since his passing...but even today, he's a credit to us.

column5: 立花くんも仕事熱心な事だな
column6: Tachibana's certainly devoted to his job.

column5:
式典は午後３時からでしたな
お父上のように誇りをもって、一日
署長を務めあげて欲しい。
column6: The parade begins at 3:00, I believe. I'd like you to feel proud like your father and serve as chief of police for the day.

column5: よろしく頼むよ。
column6: I look forward to your performance.

column5:
式典には、遅れないように。
何といっても、今日の主役はあなた
なんだから。
column6: Don't be late for the parade. You're the one with the starring role, after all.

column5:
ちょっとしたアクシデントが
あった様だがね。\n
ま、心配はないよ。
column6: It sounds like there's been a bit of an accident. Well, no need to worry.

column5:
メイ！\n
すまんが、邪魔をしないでくれ。
column6: May! Sorry, but don't get in the way.

column5: 何かあったんですか？
column6: Did something happen?

column5:
いや、何でもない。\n
何でも首を突っ込みたがるのは、悪
いクセだぞ。
column6: No, it's nothing. Sticking your nose into everything's a bad habit, yeah?

column5:
すまんが急ぎの用ができた。
それじゃな。
column6: Sorry, but something's come up I've got to deal with fast. Bye.

column5: おおっ?!
column6: Oh!?

column5: お願い！パパを探して!!
column6: Please! Find Papa!!

column5: え？パ、パパ？ええぇ？?!
column6: Huh? P-Papa? HUUUH!?

column5:
パパが帰ってこないの‥‥。
お願い、パパを探して！
column6:
Papa hasn't come home...\n
Please, find Papa!

column5:
さ、探してって‥困るよぉ。
ボクには、無理だよ。
column6: F-find him...That's a lot to deal with. I can't do that.

column5: ‥‥うっく‥。
あぁあ‥泣いちゃいましたよ
column6: Aaah...She's started crying.

column5:
しょ、しょうがないなぁ。\n
泣かれちゃったら、ほっとく訳には
いかないよ。
column6: I-I guess I don't have a choice. If she's crying, there's no way I can leave her alone.

column5:
ね、ね、泣かないで。\n
少しなら助けてあげられるかもしれ
ないから‥。
column6:
Hey, hey, don't cry.\n
I might be able to help you out a _little_ bit, okay...?

column5:
だから、ね。\n
もう泣かないで。
column6: So...don't cry any more, okay?

column5: ホント?!
column6: Really!?

column5: う‥うん。
column6: Y...yeah.

column5:
とにかく、彼女の話を聞かな
いことには、何も始まりませんね。
column6: Well, we're not going to get anywhere without listening to what she has to say.

column5:
\c<$0B>[II]ボタン\c<$0F>を押して、\c<$0B>事情を聞
く\c<$0F>を実行してください。
column6: Press the \c<$0B>II Button\c<$0F>, and use the \c<$0B>Ask Situation\c<$0F> command.

column5:
眼鏡やら化粧品やら‥いろん
な小道具がありますね。
column6: Glasses, cosmetics...There are a bunch of little tools inside.

column5:
そりゃ、ＴＶ局のバスだもん
当たり前だよ。\n
バスの中で、メイクするんだから。
column6: I mean, yeah? It's a TV studio bus. They do makeup in it, so of course there are.

column5:
どうしたメイ？\n
２時半までは自由にしていいんだぜ
column6:
What's the deal, May?\n
You can do whatever you want till 2:30, y'know.

column5:
沢田と話す\n
優子の事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Talk to Sawada\n
Ask about Yuuko\n
Leave

column5:
あの洋館以来ですよね‥沢田
さんと仕事するのは。
column6: I guess it's the first time since the mansion...that we've worked together, I mean.

column5:
そうだな。\n
綾華には気の毒だったが‥。メイが
元気そうでよかったよ。
column6:
Guess so.\n
It was awful, what happened to Ayaka, but...Good to see you're looking cheerful, May.

column5:
しかし、ずいぶんと活躍した
そうじゃないか。\n
素子から聞いてるぞ。
column6: But you're sure keeping yourself busy, eh? Heard about it from Motoko.

column5: あの、おしゃべり‥。
column6: That chatterbox...

column5:
それにしてもだな‥。その‥
メイの後ろにいる子は誰だ？\n
メイの子供か？
column6:
So, uh, May...umm...\n
Who's the tagalong back there? Your kid?

column5:
[2x]\s<$01>バッ、\n
\n
[1x]\s<$03>バカな事を言わないで下さい！
column6:
[2x]\s<$01>D...[1x][br3]
[br3]
\s<$03>Don't say stupid stuff!

column5:
ちょっとワケがあって‥‥、
この子のお父さんを、探す事になっ
ちゃったんです。
column6: Look, there's a reason for it...I've gotten sucked into looking for this girl's dad.

column5:
ふぅん。\n
ま、何も言うつもりはないが、あん
まり変なことに巻き込まれるなよ。
column6:
Hmm.\n
Well, don't take this the wrong way, but try not to get caught up in anything too weird.

column5:
悪いが、おれは協力してやれ
んよ。
column6: Sorry, can't help ya.

column5:
心配するほどの事でもないだ
ろうが、危険な事になりそうなら、
警察にまかせるんだぞ。
column6: It's probably nothing to get worked up about, but if it looks like it's gonna be serious, leave it up to the police.

column5:
‥罪を認めている様だな。\n
近く裁判が行われるらしいが、検察
は５年程度の懲役を求めるらしい。
column6: ...Apparently, she's admitted her guilt. The trial's gonna be soon, but I hear the prosecution's seeking five years' imprisonment with labor.

column5:
たぶん、求刑通りになるだろ
うな‥。
column6: I'm guessing they'll get the sentence they want...

column5: 大変そうだね。
column6: That looks tough.

column5:
それほどでもないですよ。\n
メイさんこそ、休憩しておいた方が
いいですよ。
column6:
This isn't that big a deal.\n
May, _you_ should go take a break.

column5:
笹木と話す\n
作業の事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Talk to Sasaki\n
Ask about work\n
Leave

column5:
あ、え〜と‥メイさん。\n
よかったら、今度の休みに映画でも
‥どうです？
column6:
Ah, umm...May.\n
How'd you feel if maybe next day off, we...go see a movie?

column5:
いいよ\n
いやだ
column6:
Sure\n
No way

column5:
別にいいけど‥。\n
あはは、ひょっとしてデートに誘っ
てるつもり？
column6:
That's fine, I guess, but...\n
Ah-ha-ha, you're not trying to ask me on a date here, right?

column5: まんざらでもないくせに。
column6: ...You say, not sounding very upset.

column5:
ナビ！\n
素子みたいな事を言わないでよ。
column6:
Navi!\n
Quit talking like Motoko.

column5: いやだよ。
column6: Yeah, no thanks.

column5: じゃ、次の次の休みなら？
column6: Okay, then how about the day off after the next?

column5:
くすくす。\n
めげないんだねぇ。
column6: Hee-hee. Not discouraged, huh?

column5: 逆境には強いんですよ。
column6: I stand strong in the face of adversity.

column5:
そういえば、１時間くらい前
だったかな？
column6: By the way, maybe...an hour or so ago?

column5:
素子さんとかんなさんが、こ
こに来ましたよ。
column6: Motoko and Kanna came by here.

column5:
メイさんの晴れ舞台をメチャ
メチャにしてやるんだって言ってま
したけどね。
column6: They were talking about how they're going to mess up your moment in the spotlight, though.

column5:
ど‥、どうしたんです、その
子は？
column6: Wh...what's up with that girl?

column5:
うん、それがさ。\n
ひょんな事で、この子のお父さんを
探す事になっちゃって‥。
column6:
Yeah, about that.\n
Somehow, I've gotten saddled with finding this girl's dad...

column5:
お願いですから、あまり危険
な事はしないでくださいよ。
column6: Please, don't do anything too dangerous, okay?

column5:
式典の準備は、ほとんど終っ
てるんですよ。
column6: The setup for the parade is practically finished.

column5:
他のスタッフ達も、みんな休
憩に行っちゃいました。
column6: The other guys on staff have all gone off to take a break.

column5:
今は機材が確実につながって
いるか、チェックしてるんです。
column6: Right now, I'm checking that the machinery is hooked up securely.

column5: あ、お疲れ様です。
column6: Oh, thanks for your hard work.

column5:
２時半までには、戻って
きて下さいね。
column6: Please be back by 2:30, okay?

column5: どこに行きます？
column6: Where are we going?

column5:
１丁目　　　　　２丁目\n
行かない
column6:
District 1
[sp]<$70>
District 2
\n

column6:
District 1
[sp]<$70>
District 2
\n

District 3

column5: 外に出ますか？
column6: Are you leaving?

column5:
外に出る\n
外に出ない
column6:
Leave\n
Don't leave

column5:
看板の文字が読めないの
か？\n
今は準備中だ。
column6: Can't you read the sign? I'm setting up right now.

column5:
聞こえなかったのか？\n
今は準備中だ。
column6: Didn't you hear me? I'm setting up right now.

column5:
あらぁ、メイさん。\n
お久しぶりですぅ。
column6:
Oh, myyy, Miss Maaay.\n
It's been so looong.

column5:
あぁ！あなたはっ！\n
だ、誰だっけ？
column6:
Aah! It's _you_!\n
Wh-who are you again?

column5:
あ、あれ?!\n
『静かの海』号でウェイトレスして
たんじゃなかったっけ？
column6:
H-huh!?\n
Weren't you working as a waitress on the Silent Sea?

column5: なんで、こんな所に？
column6: What are you doing here?

column5:
児島であんな事件があっ
たでしょぉ。
column6: There was that incident on Kojima, riiight?

column5:
で、しばらくの間『静か
の海』号が運休になっちゃってぇ‥
column6: So, the Silent Sea's service got suspended for a whillle...

column5:
だから、この店でアルバ
イト始めたんですぅ。
column6: That's why I started working part-time heeere.

column5:
あいかわらず、この人と話す
と調子が狂うなぁ‥。
column6: Talking to this woman throws me off as much as ever...

column5:
忘れちゃったんですかぁ
ひどいですぅ‥。
column6:
You forgot about meee?\n
You're awfuuul...

column5:
ほらぁ、『静かの海』号
でウェイトレスしてた田中ですよぉ
column6: Come ooon...I'm Tanaka, the waitress from the Silent Seeea.

column5:
指輪が盗まれた事件が、
あったじゃないですかぁ。
column6: There was that thing where a ring got stolen, rememberrr?

column5:
‥‥あ、思い出した。\n
で、でも‥どうしてこんな所に？
column6:
...Oh, that's right.\n
B-but...what are you doing here?

column5:
お求めの品がございまし
たらぁ、お申しつけ下さいね。\n
それでは、ごゆっくりぃ。
column6: If there is anything you neeed, please do aaask. Well, take it eeeasy.

column5:
へぇ、ＯＲＵＫＡ対応のパソ
コンも発売されたんですねぇ。
column6: Ooh...So they're selling Oruka-compatible PCs too?

column5: オ、ＯＲＵＫＡ対応？
column6: O...Oruka-compatible?

column5:
別売されてる光ケーブルで、
ＯＲＵＫＡと接続出来るんです。
column6: They can link up to Oruka using a separately-sold optical cable.

column5:
ＯＲＵＫＡがパソコンを操作
できるようになるんですよ。
column6: It enables Oruka to operate the PC.

column5:
だから使用者はＯＲＵＫＡと
会話するだけで、コンピュータを使
う事が出来るようになるんです。
column6: Thus, the user becomes able to manipulate the computer simply by talking to Oruka.

column5:
これは、ＯＲＵＫＡ対応の最
新型パソコンですからね。
column6: This is the latest model of Oruka-compatible PC.

column5:
接続ケーブルさえあれば、ナ
ビがコンピュータを操ってみせます
よ。
column6: If we just had the link cable, Navi would definitely be able to use the computer.

column5:
あれ、ナビも売られてるじゃ
ない。
column6: Oh, they're selling you too, Navi.

column5: ナビはナビだけですって。
column6: Come on, Navi is _only_ Navi.

column5:
商品名はＯＲＵＫＡだって、
言ったじゃないですか！
column6: Haven't I _told_ you that the product's name is Oruka!?

column5:
高い割にはＯＲＵＫＡも、そ
こそこ売れてるみたいですね。
column6: It seems like Oruka is selling at a fairly good rate.

column5:
街でＯＲＵＫＡをしている人
を、たまに見かけますもの。
column6: I see people in the city wearing it from time to time.

column5:
メイ！まさか、お金を盗むつ
もりじゃないでしょうね。
column6: May! You're not thinking of stealing the money, are you!?

column5:
あ、あのねぇ‥。\n
信用しなさいよ！
column6: Excuse me...Have a little faith in me, will you!?

column5:
まるで森の中でテレビを見て
る気分ですよね。
column6: It feels just like we're watching TV in a forest.

column5:
小さな店ですけど、在庫は豊
富みたいですねぇ。
column6: It's a small shop, but they have plentiful stock.

column5: 電話機も売ってるんですね。
column6: So they sell telephones, too.

column5:
ボクも留守番電話、買おうか
な‥。
column6: Maybe I should buy an answerphone...

column5:
ムダ遣いはやめましょうよ。
どうせ電話してくれる人もいないん
ですから。
column6: Don't waste your money. It's not like there's anyone who'd call you anyway.

column5:
ＭＥＣ製のモニタ一体型パソ
コンですね。
column6: It's a monitor-body PC made by MEC.

column5:
拡張性には乏しいですけど、
お値段が手ごろなんですよ。
column6: Though lacking in terms of extensibility, it's modestly priced.

column5:
ナビ。いつからセールスを始
めるようになったの？
column6: Navi...Since when are you a salesperson?

column5: ‥なんの用？
column6: ...What do you want?

column5:
園木の事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask about Sonoki\n
Leave

column5: 知らないわよ、そんな事。
column6: I don't know anything about that.

column5: はいは〜い‥。
column6: Coming, comiiing...

column5:
あら、あなたニュースに出て
た‥あぁ、何とかっていう女優さん
じゃない？
column6: Oh, my, you're that...ahh, actress or something from the news?

column5: お隣さん？
column6: My neighbor?

column5:
さあねぇ、あまりおつき合い
がないから、よく分かんないけど‥
家にいない時が多いみたいよ。
column6: Well, see, we don't associate much, so I don't really know him, but...it seems like he's away from home a lot.

column5:
あ、それからさ。\n
４丁目で何かあったの知ってる？
column6: Oh yeah, and...have you heard that something happened in District 4?

column5:
さっき、たまたま通ってきた
んだけど。お巡りたちが、ふっるい
アパートを調べてたのよ。
column6: I happened to walk by there a little while ago. Some officers were investigating this _ancient_ apartment.

column5:
なんかよく分かんないけど、
がんばってね！
column6: I don't really know what this is about, but good luck!

column5: 留守みたいですね。
column6: It looks like no one's home.

column5:
ここが友美お姉ちゃんの部屋な
の。
column6: This is Miss Tomomi's room.

column5:
ここが、葉のうち。\n
いま鍵を開けるね。
column6: This is Yoh's house. I'll unlock it now.

column5:
ところでさ。葉のお父さんは
どんなお仕事をしてたの？
column6: By the way, Yoh, what kind of job does your father have?

column5:
ん〜‥よく分かんない。\n
パパは、お仕事の事は教えてくれな
かったもの。
column6:
Mmm...I dunno, really.\n
Papa wouldn't tell me about work.

column5:
そっか、せめて会社の住所で
も分かれば、どこに行ったか分かり
そうなんだけどな‥。
column6: Oh...If you at least knew his company's address, I might have known where to go...

column5: ここがパパの部屋だよ。
column6: This is Papa's room.

column5:
あ〜あ、人様の部屋を勝手に
探ることになるなんて‥はぁ。
column6: Aaaah, this has turned into rifling through someone else's room...(sigh).

column5:
それにしても、棚がずいぶん
多いですね。
column6: In any case, there sure are a lot of shelves.

column5:
机の横にある棚なんてファイ
ルで一杯ですけど‥どんな仕事をし
てる人なんでしょうね？
column6: The shelf next to the desk is full of files, but...what kind of job does this man have?

column5:
多機能型の留守番電話です。
この家の電話番号が書いてあります
ね。
column6: It's a multipurpose answerphone. This home's phone number is written on it.
It says it's \c<$0C>94-6157\c<$0F>.

column5:
ちょっと古い型ですけど、ま
だ十分に使えますよ。
column6: It's an older model, but it's still usable enough.

Yoh's father is a private investigator.

column6: Hey, Yoh. Haven't there been days where your dad didn't come home before?

column6: ...Yeah. But he would ALWAYS call or leave a letter or something saying `I can't come home today~!

column5:
なるほどね‥。\n

column6:
Oh, I see...}\n
(Somehow, I have a bad feeling about this.)

column5:
うん。ずっと前にできあがって
たんだけど‥。

column5:
昨日ね、学校から帰ってきたら
バラバラになって、机の上に置いて
あったの。
column6: Yesterday, when I got home from school, it was scattered all over the desk.

column5:
誰それ？\n
わたしは知らないわよ。
column6:
Who's that?\n
Never seen him.

column5:
う〜ん‥見たことないわ。\n
でもさ、何かあったの？
column6: Nooo...I've never seen him before. Um, has something happened?

column5: あ、友美お姉ちゃん！
column6: Oh, Miss Tomomi!

column5: よ、葉ちゃん?!
column6: Y-Yoh!?

column5:
ふぅ、慌てたって何も分から
ないか‥。
column6: Whew...I guess I'm not going to figure anything out if I'm all flustered...

column5:
まさか、こんな所でボクに関
係してくるとは思いもしなかったよ
column6: I could never even have imagined there was something connected to me here.

column5:
３．５インチの普通のフロッ
ピーディスクですね。パソコン用の
データを保存する為のものですよ。
column6: It's a normal 3.5-inch floppy disk. It's for storing data for use on a PC.

column5:
事件に関する手がかりが入っ
てるかも知れません。\n
持って行きましょうか。
column6: There could be some kind of clue related to the case on it. Why don't we take it with us?

事件に関する手がかりが入っ

なんだか隠し撮りでもしたみたいな
不自然なアングルですよねぇ。
column6:

It kind of feels like it was taken secretly. That's one unnatural angle!

column5:
お父さんが死んだ事に関係が

column6: Is this related to my father's death...?

column5:
調査するなら、写真を見せた
方がいいからね。\n
持って行こうか。
column6: If we're going to investigate, it'd be a good idea to show the photo around. Let's take it with us.

column5:
なるほど、中身は検案書のコ
ピーですか。
column6: I see[nbsp]-- so there's a copy of an autopsy report inside.
column7:
NOTE: so, this very critical term used repeatedly throughout the case is apparently a bit complicated.

according to my research (https://www.izumo-sosai.jp/east/knowledge/004.html), there are two kinds of documents that are generally used in Japan to officially establish a person's death. one is the 死亡診断書, which is basically a "death certificate", and is issued in cases where a person died under expected circumstances, such as after being hospitalized for a condition and receiving treatment. it is cheaper and easier to produce, being able to be written e.g. by dentists. the other kind of certificate, which is what this case is concerned with, is the 死体検案書 or just 検案書, a document produced by a doctor who carried out an autopsy under police auspices; this is done in cases of sudden or suspicious death. the form of both documents is the same; the difference is, as i understand it, largely of jurisdiction.

for simplicity, i'm going with "autopsy report" here; though this somewhat masks the implied police involvement (which is the reason Ohtaki stamps it), it's probably about the best we can do.

column5: 検案書？
column6: Autopsy report?
column7: NOTE: for the reasons explained above, may doesn't know what the document is at first. this ends up sounding a bit stupid, since we expect people to know what an "autopsy report" is just by hearing it, but there's not really a better option.

column5:
医師が死亡を確認した証明書
の事です。\n
どんな事がかいてあります？
column6: A document certifying that a doctor confirmed a death. What's written in it?

column5:
‥ともかく、もう後にはひけ
ないよ。
column6: ...Well, there's no turning back now.

column5:
葉。あなたのお父さんを必ず
見つけてあげる！
column6: Yoh. I'll definitely find your dad!

column5:
紹介するね。\n
メイお姉ちゃんだよ。\n
葉をね、助けてくれるの！
column6:
I'll introduce you.\n
This is Miss May. She's helping Yoh!

column5:
あ、初めまして。仁科友美と
申しま‥‥助ける？葉ちゃんを？
column6: Oh, nice to meet you. My name is Tomomi Nishina, and...wait, help? You, Yoh?

column5:
んもぅ、お話ならお部屋に入っ
てからにしようよぉ。
column6: C'mooon, go inside if we're gonna talk.

column5: え？ええ、そ、そうね。
column6: Huh? R-right, yes.

column5:
ど、どうぞ。遠慮なさらない
であがってくださいな。
column6: W-welcome. Please, come in and make yourself at home.

column5:
‥そうだったんですか‥‥。
本当に申し訳ありません。ご迷惑を
おかけして‥。
column6:
...So that's what happened...\n
I'm so, so sorry. I've caused you such trouble...

column5: ううん、いいんです。
column6: No, it's fine.

column5:
ボクにとっても重要な事だっ
てわかったし‥、最後まで調べるつ
もり。
column6: I've found out about something really important to me, so...I'm planning to see this through to the end.

column5: そうですか‥。
column6: I see...

column5:
たいした事はできませんけど
私に出来ることなら、ご協力させて
いただきますわ。
column6: I can't offer much, but if there's anything I can do, please let me help you out.

column5:
葉ちゃんの事は心配なさらな
いで。\n
この部屋で待っておりますから。
column6: Don't worry about Yoh. We'll be waiting in this room.

column6: But I had an engagement yesterday, so...

それじゃ、ボクはこれで失礼

葉も一緒に行く！

Wh-why!?\n

いい子だから、ここはボクに任せて

You're a good girl, so leave this to me and wait with Miss Tomomi.

column5: 葉も一緒に行きたいのにぃ。

作業は終ったの？

沢田さんのチェックが終ったら、よ

...It's about my father, so there's no way I can give up here.

column5:

A 7-year-old girl. I was supposed to be finding where her dad, a private investigator, is, but...

column6:
Tomomi Nishina\n
The manager for Yoh's apartment building. 27 years old. She's rather...gentle.

頼りになるカメラマンの沢田さん。
あの洋館の事件でも一緒だったよね
column6:
Shigeki Sawada\n
Sawada, the reliable cameraman. He was there for the mansion incident, too.

column5:

今はアシスタントディレクター。\n
あいかわらず魔法ネタが好きみたい

He's an assistant director now. Looks like he loves magic stuff as much as ever.

column5:

ボクの親友。第一印象は悪かったの
に、つきあってみるといい子だよ。
column6:
Motoko Yanagi\n
My close friend. She gives off a bad first impression, but she's a good girl if you get to know her.

column5:

洋館の事件以来だね。事件のショッ
クから立ち直ったみたいで良かった
column6:

It's been a while since the mansion incident, huh? I'm glad to see she's recovered from the shock.

column5:

column5:

今日だけは、ボクが一日署長だけど
column6:
Tsuyoshi Ohtaki\n
Chief of the Satsukigaoka Police. Just for today, _I'm_ the chief of police, though.

column5:

実は情報屋。ちょっとビックリ。
column6:
{Beast}\n
The owner of a coffee shop...or so I thought, but he's actually an information vendor. Bit of a surprise.

column5:
そのき、よう。\n
葉っぱっていう字を書いて、ようっ
て読むんだよ。
column6:
Yoh Sonoki.\n
You write it with the character for `leaf,~ and read it as `yoh.~
column7: NOTE: going by the transliteration rules we've been using for everything else, her name would be written in english as "You". this obviously has an unfortunate clash with the english pronoun system. it's particularly bad here because she talks in third person, resulting in awkward messages like "You doesn't know about that." while love live fans have apparently learned to put up with this, i feel like the potential audience for this game would rather look at something less confusing.

column5: 園木葉。７歳だよ。
column6: Yoh Sonoki. I'm 7 years old.

column5:
さつきヶ丘３丁目の２の１。\n
メゾン・ド・フルール、っていうア
パートの２０２号室。
column6:
Satsukigaoka District 3, 2-1.\n
Room 202 of the Maison de Fleur apartments.

column5:
しっかりした子ですよね。\n
まだ小さいのに、感心しますよ。
column6:
She's such a put-together girl.\n
I'm impressed even though she's still little.

column5:
３丁目のメゾン・ド・フルール
だよ。\n
２０２号室に住んでるの。
column6: It's Maison de Fleur in District 3. I live in Room 202.

column5: パパはね、園木達郎っていうの
column6: Papa is called Tatsurou Sonoki.

column5:
そのき　たつろう、ね。\n
で、パパはどこに行ったの？
column6:
Tatsurou Sonoki?\n
So, where did your papa go?

column5:
わかんないの‥。\n
昨日から、おうちに帰ってこなくて
‥‥。
column6:
I dunno...\n
He didn't come home yesterday...

column5:
友美お姉ちゃんもいなかったか
ら、葉はひとりぼっちだったの‥。
column6: Miss Tomomi wasn't there either, so Yoh was all alone...

column5:
パパがね。\n
昨日から帰ってこないの‥。
column6: Papa, he...hasn't come home since yesterday...

column5:
でも、テレビでメイ・スターが
どんな謎でも解いてくれるって言っ
てたから‥。
column6: But they were saying on TV that May Star can solve any mystery, so...

column5:
だ、誰だよぉ。\n
そんな無責任なこと言ったのは?!
column6: Wh-who? Who said something so irresponsible!?

column5: ママはいないの。
column6: Mama is gone.

column5: いない？
column6: Gone?

column5:
うん、葉が小さい頃にね。\n
死んじゃったんだって。
column6: Yeah, it was when Yoh was little. She died.

column5: あ‥ご、ごめんなさい。
column6: Oh...I-I'm sorry.

column5:
亡くなられたって聞いたじゃ
ないですか。\n
深く聞き出そうなんて無神経ですよ
column6: You heard her say she passed away, didn't you? Prying for details would be insensitive.

column5: 友美お姉さんって？
column6: `Miss Tomomi~?

column5:
う〜んとね。\n
葉のアパートの管理人さんでねえ、
いっつも葉と遊んでくれるの。
column6: Yeah, that's right. She's the manager at Yoh's apartment, and she ALWAYS plays with Yoh.

column5:
いつもは１階にいるの。\n
でも昨日は、昔のお友達に会いに行
くからって、いなかったの。
column6: She's usually on the the first floor. But yesterday, she was gone because she went to meet an old friend, she said.

column5:
だから、葉はひとりぼっちだっ
たんだよ。
column6: So, Yoh was all alone.

column5:
それにしても‥この程度の小
道具で、別人のようにキレイに化け
ましたねぇ。
column6: Gee...With just a few props like those, you've changed into an almost completely different person.

column5:
別人のようにってのは余計だ
よ！
column6: Hey, `completely different person~ is going a little far!

column5: どこに行きます？
column6: Where are we going?

column5: 外に出ますか？
column6: Are you leaving?

column5:
眼鏡やら化粧品やら‥いろん
な小道具がありますね。
column6: Glasses, cosmetics...There are a bunch of little tools inside.

column5:
看板の文字が読めないの
か？\n
今は準備中だ。
column6: Can't you read the sign? I'm setting up right now.

column5:
聞こえなかったのか？\n
今は準備中だ。
column6: Didn't you hear me? I'm setting up right now.

column5:
へぇ、ＯＲＵＫＡ対応のパソ
コンも発売されたんですねぇ。
column6: Ooh...So they're selling Oruka-compatible PCs too?

column5: オ、ＯＲＵＫＡ対応？
column6: O...Oruka-compatible?

column5:
別売されてる光ケーブルで、
ＯＲＵＫＡと接続出来るんです。
column6: They can link up to Oruka using a separately-sold optical cable.

column5:
ＯＲＵＫＡがパソコンを操作
できるようになるんですよ。
column6: It enables Oruka to operate the PC.

column5:
だから使用者はＯＲＵＫＡと
会話するだけで、コンピュータを使
う事が出来るようになるんです。
column6: Thus, the user becomes able to manipulate the computer simply by talking to Oruka.

column5:
これは、ＯＲＵＫＡ対応の最
新型パソコンですからね。
column6: This is the latest model of Oruka-compatible PC.

column5:
接続ケーブルさえあれば、ナ
ビがコンピュータを操ってみせます
よ。
column6: If we just had the link cable, Navi would definitely be able to use the computer.

column5:
あれ、ナビも売られてるじゃ
ない。
column6: Oh, they're selling you too, Navi.

column5: ナビはナビだけですって。
column6: Come on, Navi is _only_ Navi.

column5:
商品名はＯＲＵＫＡだって、
言ったじゃないですか！
column6: Haven't I _told_ you that the product's name is Oruka!?

column5:
高い割にはＯＲＵＫＡも、そ
こそこ売れてるみたいですね。
column6: It seems like Oruka is selling at a fairly good rate.

column5:
街でＯＲＵＫＡをしている人
を、たまに見かけますもの。
column6: I see people in the city wearing it from time to time.

column5:
メイ！まさか、お金を盗むつ
もりじゃないでしょうね。
column6: May! You're not thinking of stealing the money, are you!?

column5:
あ、あのねぇ‥。\n
信用しなさいよ！
column6: Excuse me...Have a little faith in me, will you!?

column5:
まるで森の中でテレビを見て
る気分ですよね。
column6: It feels just like we're watching TV in a forest.

column5:
小さな店ですけど、在庫は豊
富みたいですねぇ。
column6: It's a small shop, but they have plentiful stock.

column5: 電話機も売ってるんですね。
column6: So they sell telephones, too.

column5:
ボクも留守番電話、買おうか
な‥。
column6: Maybe I should buy an answerphone...

column5:
ムダ遣いはやめましょうよ。
どうせ電話してくれる人もいないん
ですから。
column6: Don't waste your money. It's not like there's anyone who'd call you anyway.

column5:
ＭＥＣ製のモニタ一体型パソ
コンですね。
column6: It's a monitor-body PC made by MEC.

column5:
拡張性には乏しいですけど、
お値段が手ごろなんですよ。
column6: Though lacking in terms of extensibility, it's modestly priced.

column5:
ナビ。いつからセールスを始
めるようになったの？
column6: Navi...Since when are you a salesperson?

column5:
多機能型の留守番電話です。
この家の電話番号が書いてあります
ね。
column6: It's a multipurpose answerphone. This home's phone number is written on it.
It says it's \c<$0C>94-6157\c<$0F>.

column5:
ちょっと古い型ですけど、ま
だ十分に使えますよ。
column6: It's an older model, but it's still usable enough.

column5:
パソコンを起動する\n
やめる

Boot the PC\n

column5:
まさか本物の探偵さんの行方
を探すことになるなんて、思いもし
なかったよ‥。
column6: I never imagined we'd end up trying to hunt down an actual detective...

column5:
法律関係の書籍が圧倒的に多
いですね。他にも医学書や薬学書な
どの専門書でいっぱいです。
column6: There are an overwhelming number of books related to law. It's also full of specialty books on medicine and pharmaceutics.

column5:
ジグソーパズルを組み立てる\n
組み立て方法の説明\n
やめる
column6:
Put together the jigsaw puzzle\n
How to put it together\n
Quit

column5:
バラバラになっているピース
を組み立てて、絵を完成させてくだ
さい。
column6: Put the scattered pieces together and complete the picture.

column5:
\c<$0B>[I]ボタン\c<$0F>で\c<$0C>ピースを取ったり
置いたり\c<$0F>する事が出来ます。
column6: You can pick up and put down pieces with the \c<$0B>I Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
各ピースには表と裏があり、
ピースを持って\c<$0B>[II]ボタン\c<$0F>を押せば、\c<$0C>
表と裏を切り替え\c<$0F>られます。
column6: Each piece has a front and a back. If you hold a piece and press the \c<$0B>II Button\c<$0F>, you can \c<$0C>switch between the front and back\c<$0F>.

column5:
\c<$0C>中断\c<$0F>する時は、ピースを置い
てから\c<$0B>[II]ボタン\c<$0F>を押してください。
column6: To \c<$0C>stop\c<$0F>, after dropping a piece, press the \c<$0B>II Button\c<$0F>.

column5:
ふぅ、慌てたって何も分から
ないか‥。
column6: Whew...I guess I'm not going to figure anything out if I'm all flustered...

column5:
まさか、こんな所でボクに関
係してくるとは思いもしなかったよ
column6: I could never even have imagined there was something connected to me here.

column5:
３．５インチの普通のフロッ
ピーディスクですね。パソコン用の
データを保存する為のものですよ。
column6: It's a normal 3.5-inch floppy disk. It's for storing data for use on a PC.

column5:
事件に関する手がかりが入っ
てるかも知れません。\n
持って行きましょうか。
column6: There could be some kind of clue related to the case on it. Why don't we take it with us?

column5:
\n
\c<$09>　『ディスク』を取りました。\c<$0F>
column6:
[br3]
#SETPADANDCENTER(0, 224)
\c<$09>Took the disk.\c<$0F>
#DISABLEPADANDCENTER()

column5:
事件に関する手がかりが入っ
てるかも知れませんね。
column6: Maybe there's some kind of clue related to the case on it?

column5:
写真ですね‥誰でしょう？\n
なんだか隠し撮りでもしたみたいな
不自然なアングルですよねぇ。
column6:
It's a photograph...of who?\n
It kind of feels like it was taken secretly. That's one unnatural angle!

column5: 何か分かりました？
column6: Have you figured anything out?

column5:
聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:

\n

column5:
園木さんは、３年前からこち
らにお住まいなんですけれど‥。
column6: Mr. Sonoki has lived here for three years now, but...

column5:
ご自分の事は、あまりお話さ
れない方で、どんなお仕事をされて
いるのか、よく存じておりませんの
column6: He isn't the sort to talk about his affairs, and I don't know what kind of job he has.

column5:
ただ、今までもお帰りになら
なかった日もありましたから‥。
column6: But there have previously been days where he didn't return home...

column5:
今回も心配する程の事ではな
いと思うのですが‥。
column6: I wouldn't think this time is anything to worry about.

column5:
明るくて元気な子でしょ？\n
私なんかより、よっぽどしっかりし
てるんですよ。
column6: Isn't she a happy and spirited girl? She's much more collected than someone like me.

column5:
生まれてすぐにお母さんを亡
くしたそうで‥。\n
きっと大変だったでしょうに‥。
column6: I heard her mother passed away soon after she was born...It must have been terribly tough...

column5:
このアパートの管理人をして
るんです。
column6: I serve as manager for these apartments.

column5:
園木さんがお帰りになれない
時は、いつも私が葉ちゃんと一緒に
いたんですけど‥。
column6: When Mr. Sonoki can't come home, I always stay with Yoh.

column5:
でも、昨日は私も約束があっ
たので‥。
column6: But I had an engagement yesterday, so...

column5:
事件の事を話す\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask about the case\n
Leave

column5:
ふ〜ん、そんな事があったん
ですか‥‥。
column6: Hmm, so that's what's going on...

column5:
ボクは、そのディスクで表示
された文章の内容が、気になります
ね。
column6: I'm interested in what was in the document on that disk.

column5:
いかにもオカルト的じゃない
ですか。\n
問題は何を暗示しているか‥‥。
column6: It's really occult-ish, isn't it? The question is what it's hinting at...

column5:
園木っていう人も、探偵でも
何でもなくて‥。案外、魔術結社の
一員だったりしてね。
column6: What kind of detective is this Sonoki guy supposed to be...? He's somehow in a magic society or something, huh?

column5:
やっぱり、ディスクで表示さ
れた文章が鍵じゃないでしょうか？
column6: Maybe the document on the disk is the key?

column5:
本当にオカルトかどうかはと
もかく、なんらかの暗号に思えます
けど。
column6: I mean, regardless of whether it's actually occult or not, I'd think it's some kind of code.

column5:
やれやれ、やっかいな事に巻
き込まれやがって‥。
column6: Good grief, you've gone and gotten tangled up in some bad business again...

column5:
危険な目にあう前に、力ずく
でも止めさせるべきかもしれんな。
column6: Maybe you should say enough's enough and get out while the going's good.

column5:
大丈夫だって！\n
‥お父さんの事だもの、ここでやめ
る訳にはいかないよ。
column6:
Look, I'll be fine!\n
...It's about my father, so there's no way I can give up here.

column5:
まったく、大事になる前に相
談しに来るんだぞ！
column6: Geez, come talk to me before things get too heavy!

column5: ごくろうさま！
column6: Thanks for all the hard work!

column5:
え‥メ、メイさんですか?!\n
どうしたんです、その格好？
column6:
Uh...M-May?\n
Why are you dressed like that?

column5: あはは、ちょっとね。
column6: Ah-ha-ha...Well, you know.

column5: お疲れ様です！
column6: Thanks for all your hard work!

column5:
メ、メイか?!\n
どうしたんだ、そんな格好で！
column6:
M-May!?\n
What're you dressed like _that_ for!?

column5:
ど、どうしたんですか？
式典はまだ始まりませんよ。
column6:
Wh-what is it?\n
The parade isn't starting yet.

column5:
え？\n
もう着替えたんですか。\n
式典まで、まだ時間がありますよ。
column6:
Huh?\n
You've already changed? It's still a while before the parade.

column5:
園木の事を聞く\n
写真を見せる\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask about Sonoki\n
Show the photo\n
Leave

column5: 留守みたいですね。
column6: It looks like no one's home.

column5:
なるほど、中身は検案書のコ
ピーですか。
column6: I see[nbsp]-- so there's a copy of an autopsy report inside.

column5: 検案書？
column6: Autopsy report?

column5:
医師が死亡を確認した証明書
の事です。\n
どんな事がかいてあります？
column6: A document certifying that a doctor confirmed a death. What's written in it?

column5:
女の子だねぇ。部屋がぬいぐ
るみだらけだよ。
column6: Well, she _is_ a girl. Her room's full of stuffed animals.

column5:
メイさん？‥警察の方だった
んですか？
column6: May?...Are you a police officer?

column5: 違うって‥。
column6: Um, no...

column5:
わあぁ！\n
メイお姉ちゃん、かっこいいぃ！
column6:
WHOA!\n
Miss May, you're soooo cool!

column5:
葉ね、ちゃんと友美お姉ちゃん
と一緒に待ってるよ。
column6: Yoh is waiting with Miss Tomomi like a good girl, see?

column5:
お求めの品がございまし
たらぁ、お申しつけ下さいね。\n
それでは、ごゆっくりぃ。
column6: If there is anything you neeed, please do aaask. Well, take it eeeasy.

column5:
しっかし‥変装してたつもり
だったんだけど、よくボクだって分
かったよねぇ。
column6: Wait...I was trying to disguise myself, but she figured out it was me no problem.

column5:
あらぁ、メイさん。\n
お久しぶりですぅ。
column6:
Oh, myyy, Miss Maaay.\n
It's been so looong.

column5:
あぁ！あなたはっ！\n
だ、誰だっけ？
column6:
Aah! It's _you_!\n
Wh-who are you again?

column5:
あ、あれ?!\n
『静かの海』号でウェイトレスして
たんじゃなかったっけ？
column6:
H-huh!?\n
Weren't you working as a waitress on the Silent Sea?

column5: なんで、こんな所に？
column6: What are you doing here?

column5:
児島であんな事件があっ
たでしょぉ。
column6: There was that incident on Kojima, riiight?

column5:
で、しばらくの間『静か
の海』号が運休になっちゃってぇ‥
column6: So, the Silent Sea's service got suspended for a whillle...

column5:
だから、この店でアルバ
イト始めたんですぅ。
column6: That's why I started working part-time heeere.

column5:
あいかわらず、この人と話す
と調子が狂うなぁ‥。
column6: Talking to this woman throws me off as much as ever...

column5:
忘れちゃったんですかぁ
ひどいですぅ‥。
column6:
You forgot about meee?\n
You're awfuuul...

column5:
ほらぁ、『静かの海』号
でウェイトレスしてた田中ですよぉ
column6: Come ooon...I'm Tanaka, the waitress from the Silent Seeea.

column5:
指輪が盗まれた事件が、
あったじゃないですかぁ。
column6: There was that thing where a ring got stolen, rememberrr?

column5:
‥‥あ、思い出した。\n
で、でも‥どうしてこんな所に？
column6:
...Oh, that's right.\n
B-but...what are you doing here?

column5: ‥何かあったんでしょうか？
column6: ...Has something happened?
column7: NOTE: i think this woman and the officer at the front of the apartment are the only people in the game who are actually fooled by may's ingenious disguise

column5: いえ‥、私は知りません。
column6: No...I don't know about him.

column5:
どなたでしょう？\n
私は知りませんけど。
column6:
Who is this person?\n
I'm afraid I don't know him.

column5:
‥あらぁ、どうしたの？\n
そんな格好しちゃって。
column6:
...Oh, my, what happened?\n
Why're you dressed like that?

column5: ‥あら、今度はなぁに？
column6: ...Oh, my, what is it now?

column5: メイ‥ばれてますよ。\n
column6: May...You've been found out.}\n
column7: NOTE: these two lines display in the same box...for no real reason

column5: 自信なくすなぁ。
column6: I'm gonna lose my confidence...

column5: はいは〜い‥。
column6: Coming, comiiing...

column5: お隣さん？
column6: My neighbor?

column5:
さあねぇ、あまりおつき合い
がないから、よく分かんないけど‥
家にいない時が多いみたいよ。
column6: Well, see, we don't associate much, so I don't really know him, but...it seems like he's away from home a lot.

column5:
なんかよく分かんないけど、
がんばってね。
column6: I don't really know what this is about, but good luck.
column7: NOTE: almost dupe of 3861 except with period instead of exclamation mark

column5:
う〜ん‥見たことないわ。\n
でもさ、何かあったの？
column6: Nooo...I've never seen him before. Um, has something happened?

column5:
ふぅ‥女優やってて良かった
よ。
column6: Whew...Thank goodness I'm an actress.

column5:
アドリブで演技ができる様に
なったもんね。
column6: That's how I can perform ad lib, after all.

column5:
どうしました？\n
事件現場は、一番奥の４号室ですよ
column6:
What's wrong?\n
The crime scene is Room 4, the furthest one in.

column5:
留守かな？\n
ま、こんな騒ぎじゃ、部屋にいる訳
ないか。
column6:
Nobody's home?\n
Well, I guess no one would be in their room in this uproar.

column5:
げ‥やっば〜。\n
主任刑事って、立花さんだったんだ
column6:
Gah...Whoops!\n
The head detective was Mr. Tachibana!

column5:
何しに来た!!\n
ここは子供の来るところじゃない！
column6:
What're you doing here!?\n
This is no place for kids!

column5:
全く、何をしていた！\n
部外者を中に入れるなと、言っただ
ろう!!
column6:
The hell are you doing!?\n
Didn't I _tell_ you not to let any outsiders through!?

column5:
変装もムダになっちゃいまし
たね‥。\n
普段着に着替えます？
column6: Guess the disguise ended up being useless...Are you going to change back to your normal clothes?

column5:
ううん。\n
この格好も気に入っちゃったからね
column6:
Nah.\n
I've taken a shine to this look, too.

column5: 何になさいます？
column6: What would you like?

column5:
メ〜イ〜。何しようとしてる
んです？
column6: Maaay. What do you think you're doing?
column7: NOTE: examing the cash register in MAGSAX

column5: なんか楽しそうだね。
column6: You look like you're having fun.

column5:
よぉ、メイか。\n
いや、聞いてやってくれよ。
column6:
Oh, May?\n
Hey, listen to this.

column5:
よぉ、メイ。\n
式典まで時間はあるが、もう着替え
たのか？
column6:
Oh, May.\n
We've got time till the parade, but you've already changed clothes?

column5:
いや、それより聞いてやって
くれよ。
column6: Well, anyway, listen to this.

column5:
笹木の奴が大学で『オカルト
研究会』にいた話は知ってるか？
column6: You know how Sasaki here was in the `Occult Research Society~ in college?

column5:
で、学生の時に、メンバーと
一緒に１丁目の廃ビルに忍び込んだ
だと。
column6: Well, he says when he was a student, he and the members snuck into the abandoned building in District 1.

column5:
いや、その‥幽霊が出るって
噂だったもので‥。
column6: Ah, well...There were rumors about ghosts appearing, see...

column5:
それで廃ビルの地下駐車場に
行ってきたんですけどね。
column6: So, we went to the parking garage in the abandoned building.

column5:
放棄されて何年か経つのに、
車が停めてあったんですよ。
column6: There were cars parked there even though it'd been a few years since it was abandoned.

column5:
まぁ結局は、幽霊なんてでな
かったんで、写真を撮って帰ってき
たんですけど。
column6: Anyway, in the end, no ghosts or anything showed up, so I took a photo and went home.

column5:
外に出た時に警察に見つかっ
てしまいまして‥。\n
捕まっちゃったんですよ。
column6: But the police spotted us when we left...We got arrested.

column5:
真夜中だったんだろ？\n
アヤシすぎるぜ。\n
そりゃ捕まるって！
column6: It was the middle of the night, right? That's ridiculously sketchy. Of course you got arrested!

column5:
いや、お恥ずかしい話で‥。
その‥‥他の人には内緒にしといて
もらえます？
column6: Ah, could you please...you know...keep this embarrassing story secret from the others?

column5:
その後、何か進展はあったん
ですか？
column6: So, has anything happened since earlier?

column5:
事件の事を話す\n
廃ビルの事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Talk about the case\n
Ask about the abandoned building\n
Leave

column5:
廃ビルの事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask about the abandoned building\n
Leave

column5:
２年前だったかな？\n
ぼくは学生だったんですけどね。
column6:
Two years ago, was it?\n
I was a student, anyway.

column5:
その‥『オカルト研究会』っ
てのに入ってましてね。
column6: So...I'd joined this Occult Research Society, right?

column5:
幽霊の写真を撮るんだって、
メンバーと一緒に、１丁目にある廃
ビルの地下に忍び込んだんですよ。
column6: We were talking about taking pictures of ghosts, so the members and I snuck into the basement of the abandoned building in District 1.

column5:
まあ結局、何台かの車がほこ
りをかぶってただけで、何もなかっ
たんですけど。
column6: But, well, in the end, there was nothing there but some cars caked in dust.

column5:
写真だけ撮って外に出てから
が悲惨だったんですよ。
column6: Tragically, all I did was take a photo and leave.

column5:
運悪く、巡回中の警官に見つ
かって‥、アヤシイ奴らって事で捕
まっちゃいました。
column6: Then we had the bad luck to get found by a police officer making the rounds...We got arrested for being a `suspicious bunch.~

column5:
後で調べたら、５年前にビル
が放棄されるまで、向かいの警察が
駐車場を利用してたそうでして。
column6: When I looked into it later, I heard the police across the way used it for parking until the building was abandoned five years before.

column5:
それもあって、よけいアヤシ
イと思われたんでしょうかねぇ。
column6: Considering that, we just looked all the more suspicious, huh?

column5:
メイも昼飯か？\n
一緒にどうだ。
column6:
Having lunch too, May?\n
Wanna join us?

column5:
ううん。ボクはバスの中で食
べたからいいよ。
column6: No thanks. I ate in the bus, so I'm fine.

column5:
その後、危険な事はしてない
だろうな？
column6: You haven't gotten up to anything dangerous since earlier, right?

column5:
大丈夫だって。ボクだってバ
カじゃないんだから。\n
沢田さん、心配しすぎだよ。
column6: I'm telling you, I'm _fine_. I'm not an idiot, you know. You worry too much, Sawada.
column7: NOTE: no, may, i'm pretty sure he's 100% justified, what with your briliant scheme to dramatically confront a murderer one-on-one without telling anyone. right in front of a weapon display.

column5:
事件の事を話す\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask about the case\n
Leave

column5:
ふん‥その写真の男が死んで
いるのが、発見されたんだな。
column6: Hmm...So you found out the guy in that photo's dead, huh.

column5:
‥‥『組織』とやらが絡んで
いる以上、警察はあてにできない。
column6: ...With this `Syndicate~ mixed up in things, you can't rely on the police.

column5:
それに、自分の父親の事だか
ら調査をやめるわけにもいかない。
column6: And since it's about your own dad, there's no way you'll give up on investigating.

column5:
まったく、とんでもない事件
になっちまったなぁ‥。\n
メイ、こいつを持って行け。
column6:
Geez, what an absurd thing this has turned into...\n
May, take this with you.

column5: 携帯電話？
column6: A cell phone?

column5: 連絡先は分かってるな。
column6: You know my number, right?

column5:
おれの方も、何でもいいから
情報を集めてくれるように、局の連
中に頼んでおく。
column6: I'm at loose ends now, so I'll try to gather information too by asking the guys back at the station.

column5:
何かあったら、そいつで連絡
をいれろ。
column6: If anything comes up, give me a call with that thing.

column5:
\n
\c<$09>　　『携帯電話』を借りました。\c<$0F>
column6:
[br3]
#SETPADANDCENTER(0, 224)
\c<$09>Borrowed the cell phone.\c<$0F>
#DISABLEPADANDCENTER()

column5:
しっかし、本当にトラブルに
巻き込まれやすいな。
column6: Seriously, you're one hell of a trouble magnet.

column5:
何度も言うようだが、ムチャ
はするなよ。
column6: I feel like I've said this a million times, but don't do anything reckless.

column5:
あら、メイじゃない！こっち
よ、こっち！
column6: Oh, May! Over here, over here!

column5:
今の時間は、アップルパ
イとコーヒーだけだ。\n
それでいいかね。
column6: We've got nothing but apple pie and coffee this time of day. That fine?

column5:
アップルパイを注文する\n
注文しない
column6:
Order apple pie\n
Don't order

column5: 無愛想なマスターだなぁ‥。
column6: What an unfriendly host...

column5:
あらま、これ‥すっごく美味
しいよ！
column6: Oh, gee...This is REALLY delicious!

column5: なんか悔しい‥。
column6: Somehow, I'm a bit peeved...
column7: NOTE: because she can't eat, i guess?

column5:
一人一日一個ずつ。\n
これが、この店のきまりだ。
column6:
One per customer per day.\n
That's the rule at this cafe.

column5:
美味しかったのに‥。\n
へ、変な店。
column6:
Even though it was so good...?\n
Wh-what a weird cafe.

column5:
太陽を模した抽象画でしょう
か。
column6: Is that an abstract painting in the likeness of the sun?

column5:
太陽に正面からにらまれてる
みたいだよ。\n
この席は、なんかイヤだなぁ。
column6: It's like we're being glared at head-on by the sun. I kinda don't like this seat.

column5:
どうしたの、その格好？\n
式典まで、まだ時間があるんじゃな
かったっけ。
column6:
What're you wearing that for?\n
There's still time until the parade, isn't there?

column5:
いいじゃない。\n
メイ、すっごく似合ってるわ。
column6:
Oh, it's fine.\n
That really suits you, May.

column5: あ、あははは‥ありがとう。
column6: Ah, ah-ha-ha-ha...Thank you.

column5:
‥ふ〜ん。\n
メイ‥あなた、何か隠してるでしょ
column6:
...Hmm.\n
May...You're hiding something, aren't you?

column5:
悩みがあるなら言ってごらん
なさいよ。\n
相談にのるわよ。
column6: If you've got a problem, try talking about it. I'll give you advice.

column5:
なによ。\n
ようやく話す気になった？
column6:
What?\n
Finally interested in talking?

column5:
事件の事を話す\n
話さない
column6:
Talk about the case\n
Don't talk

column5: う、うそぉ。
column6: N-no way...
column7: NOTE: these two lines display in the same box, for seemingly no reason...again

column5:
あんたって‥‥ほんっとにト
ラブルに好かれてるわねぇ。
column6: ...Trouble is SERIOUSLY in love with you, huh?

column5:
ちょっと！\n
なによ、水くさいわね。
column6:
Hey!\n
What's with the silent treatment?

column5:
素子に助言を聞く\n
かんなに助言を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask Motoko for advice\n
Ask Kanna for advice\n
Leave

column5:
でも心配だわ‥。\n
誰か他の人に頼んだ方が‥‥。
column6:
I'm worried, though...\n
Wouldn't it be better to get someone else to...?

column5:
言うだけムダだって。\n
メイの性格じゃ、誰かに頼むなんて
事できないんだから。
column6:
Even saying it's useless.\n
With May's personality, she'll never be able to leave it up to someone else.

column5:
う〜ん‥事がメイのお父さん
に関わってるとなると、ヘタに冗談
も言えないしねぇ。
column6: Mmm...Now that it's got something to do with your father, I guess I can't go cracking bad jokes anymore, huh.

column5: もぉとぉこぉ〜！
column6: Moootoookooo!

column5:
‥素子に期待するのが、いけ
ないんですよ。
column6: ...You can't expect much out of Motoko.

column5:
そうねぇ‥手がかりになり
そうなのはディスクだけだけど‥。
column6: I see...The only thing thing that seems like it might be a clue is the disk, but...

column5:
かんな。あんたは気絶と頭が
いい事だけが取柄なんだからね。\n
しっかり考えてよ。
column6: Kanna, the only things you've got going for you are that you faint and you're smart. Give it a good think.

column5: そ、そんな事言われても‥
column6: B-but still, I really don't know...

column5:
探偵なんて職業の人が、宗
教とかオカルトにのめりこむのも変
な話よね。
column6: It's strange to think that someone working as a detective would fall for religious and occult stuff.

column5:
もしかしたら‥そのディス
クには別の情報も隠されてるんじゃ
ないかしら？
column6: Perhaps...there could be some other kind of information hidden on that disk, too?

column5:
ほら、パスワードみたいな
のを入力すれば、本当の情報が表示
されるとか‥。
column6: Something like, if you input a password or something, it'll show the real information...

column5:
パスワード、ねぇ‥。\n
でも、そのパスワードを探す手がか
りもないんだよね。
column6:
A password, huh...\n
But we don't have any kind of clues for finding that password.

column5:
パスワードを探す必要なんて
ないです。
column6: There's no need to look for a password.

column5:
\c<$0C>ナビをパソコンにつなげて\c<$0F>も
らえれば、ナビがディスクに隠され
た情報を探し出してみせます！
column6: If you \c<$0C>hook Navi up to a PC\c<$0F>, she'll definitely find out the information hidden on the disk!

column5:
私の考えが、間違ってなけ
ればいいんだけど‥。
column6: It'd be nice if my hunch is right, but...

column5:
現状で唯一の方針です。\n
やってみる価値はあると思いますよ
column6: It's our only lead at the moment. I think it's worth a try.

column5:
とにかく、\c<$0C>ナビをパソコンに
つなげて\c<$0F>もらえないと、何もできま
せん。
column6: In any case, if you don't \c<$0C>hook Navi up to a PC\c<$0F>, we won't be able to do anything.

column5:
沢田さんなら、ＴＶ局の方に
戻ってますよ。
column6: Sawada went back to the TV station.

column5:
戻ってくるまでには、しばら
く時間がかかると思いますけど‥。
column6: I think it'll be a little while before he gets back...

column5:
局の方でも調べてもらってま
すよ。
column6: He's getting the people at the station to investigate too.

column5:
ただ、その‥申し訳ないんで
すけど、あまり当てにならないので
はないかな、と。
column6: But, well...I hate to say it, but I don't know if we can really rely on them.

column5:
何かあったんですか？\n
沢田さんが、ずいぶん慌てていまし
たけど。
column6:
Did something happen?\n
Sawada was in quite the rush.

column5:
あ、ごめんなさい。\n
すぐに出ますから‥。
column6: Oh, I'm sorry. I'll be leaving soon...

column5: 冷やかしはお断りよ。
column6: No window-shoppers allowed.
column7:
NOTE: so, after blowing a couple hours looking through the script data hoping to find an obscure secret: it was originally intended for you to be able to order off of the menu at magsax, like at sun dance. for whatever reason, this idea was scrapped before being completed, though the alternate menu for magsax is implemented and has script data which, if forced to run by hacking the game, will result in it correctly running and the result being processed. however, all functionality beyond that consists of simple placeholders. none of this is actually used.

this message is for entering nothing when prompted for a name

column5: うちには置いてないわ。
column6: We don't carry that.
column7: NOTE: requesting an item not on the valid item list

column5: まいどあり！
column6: Thanks for your patronage!

column5: ど、どこでその情報を?!
column6: Wh-where did you find out about...!?
column7: NOTE: requesting "kemono". presumably, the idea here was to fool the player into giving the password at the wrong cafe. you'd then receive this item. most likely it would then unlock the alternate menu with the "?????" item (4418), and selecting it would do something or another.

column5: みんなには内緒だよ‥
column6: It's a secret to everybody...

column5:
\n
\c<$09>『秘密の手帳』をもらいました。\c<$0F>
column6:
[br3]
#SETPADANDCENTER(0, 224)
\c<$09>Received a secret notebook.\c<$0F>
#DISABLEPADANDCENTER()
column7: NOTE: this is completely unimplemented; the game does nothing but display this message, and doesn't actually set any kind of flag. there's no text related to the event beyond this, either. we'll just never know what was in that notebook. unless it's actually an ID card or a certificate, because 手帳 can also mean those things. (its only other use in the script is in the sense of "ID card", for something probably unrelated)

column5:
おい！\n
それ以上、中に入るんじゃない。
column6:
Hey!\n
You're not going any further than that.

column5:
お連れさん方なら、もう出て
行かれましたよ。
column6: If you're looking for your companions, they've already left.

column5:
パソコンを起動する\n
ナビを接続する\n
やめる
column6:
Boot the PC\n
Attach Navi\n
Quit

column5:
このパソコンではムリです。
ＯＲＵＫＡ対応の最新型パソコンで
ないと、つながりませんよ。
column6:
This PC won't work.\n
I can't hook up to it if it's not a new, Oruka-compatible PC.

column5:
はい、ＯＲＵＫＡの接続
ケーブルですねぇ。
column6: Okay, an Oruka link cable, is iiit?

column5: どうぞぉ。
column6: Here you gooo.

column5:
どうぞぉ。\n
自由に使ってくださって構いません
からぁ。
column6:
Go right aheaaad.\n
You may use them as you pleeease.

column5:
これ！これですよ。\n
ＯＲＵＫＡ対応のパソコンです。
column6:
This! It's this one.\n
This is an Oruka-compatible PC.

column5: オ、ＯＲＵＫＡ対応？
column6: O...Oruka-compatible?

column5:
別売されてる光ケーブルで、
ＯＲＵＫＡと接続できるんです。
column6: They can link up to Oruka using a separately-sold optical cable.
column7: NOTE: these three messages are near-dupes of 3832-3834 with very tiny wording differences. they'll be effectively identical in translation anyway, so i'm just aliasing them.

column5:
ＯＲＵＫＡがパソコンを操作
できるようになるんです。
column6: It enables Oruka to operate the PC.

column5:
だから、使用者はＯＲＵＫＡ
と会話するだけで、コンピュータを
使えるようになるんですよ。
column6: Thus, the user becomes able to manipulate the computer simply by talking to Oruka.

column5:
要するに、ディスクを調べる
には、このパソコンにナビをつなげ
ればいいんだね？
column6: So what you're saying is that in order to search the disk, we should hook you up to this PC, Navi?

column5:
ええ。幸いにも、この店で接
続ケーブルも売られてますしね。
column6: Yes. Luckily for us, they're selling the link cable at this store too.

column5: さて、接続したよ。
column6: All right, it's connected.

column5:
パソコンを起動する\n
動作原理を聞く\n
ナビをはずす
column6:
Boot the PC\n
Hear the operating principles\n
Disconnect Navi
column7: NOTE: there is a 99% chance they were going to have a minigame here, ran out of time and scrapped it, and left the flavor text part of the instructions as the useless "operating principles" option

column5:
ナビのホログラム機能を利用
してるんです。
column6: Navi is making use of her hologram feature.

column5:
ホログラムのレーザー光で、
光ケーブルを通して信号をパソコン
に送って、操作してるんですよ。
column6: Using the hologram's laser beam, I'm sending signals to and controlling the PC through the optical cable.

column5:
\c<$09>『ＯＲＵＫＡ接続ケーブル』を\n
買いました。\c<$0F>
column6:
[br3]
#SETPADANDCENTER(0, 224)
\c<$09>Bought the {Oruka Link Cable.}\c<$0F>
#DISABLEPADANDCENTER()

column5:
それとね、ちょっとお願いが
あるんだけど‥。
column6: Hey, by the way, I wanted to ask you a favor...

column5:
ちょっとだけ、店頭にあるパ
ソコン使わせてくれない？
column6: Could you let me use the PCs in the storefront just a little?

column5:
はぁ、メイさんのお願い
ですからぁ、構いませんけどぉ。
column6: Huuuh...Since it's you asking, Miss Maaay, it's all riiight.

column5: ディスクを解析中です。
column6: Now analyzing disk.

column5: プロテクト発見。解除中。
column6: Protection found. Cracking.

column5:
解析終了。\n
情報を画面に表示します。
column6:
Analysis complete.\n
I'll display the information on the screen.

column5:
園木　葉　（そのき　よう）\n
７歳の女の子。私立探偵のお父さん
の行方を探すはずだったんだけど‥
column6:
Yoh Sonoki\n
A 7-year-old girl. I was supposed to be finding where her dad, a private investigator, is, but...

column5:
仁科　友美　（にしな　ともみ）\n
葉のアパートの管理人さん。２７歳
ちょっと‥だいぶおっとりしてる。
column6:
Tomomi Nishina\n
The manager for Yoh's apartment building. 27 years old. She's rather...gentle.

column5:
沢田　重樹　（さわだ　しげき）\n
頼りになるカメラマンの沢田さん。
あの洋館の事件でも一緒だったよね
column6:
Shigeki Sawada\n
Sawada, the reliable cameraman. He was there for the mansion incident, too.

column5:
笹木　忠雄　（ささき　ただお）\n
今はアシスタントディレクター。\n
あいかわらず魔法ネタが好きみたい
column6:
Tadao Sasaki\n
He's an assistant director now. Looks like he loves magic stuff as much as ever.

column5:
柳　素子　（やなぎ　もとこ）\n
ボクの親友。第一印象は悪かったの
に、つきあってみるといい子だよ。
column6:
Motoko Yanagi\n
My close friend. She gives off a bad first impression, but she's a good girl if you get to know her.

column5:
三原　かんな　（みはら　かんな）
洋館の事件以来だね。事件のショッ
クから立ち直ったみたいで良かった
column6:
Kanna Mihara\n
It's been a while since the mansion incident, huh? I'm glad to see she's recovered from the shock.

column5:
立花　次郎　（たちばな　じろう）
あいかわらずの刑事さん。さつきヶ
丘警察署にいたとは知らなかった。
column6:
Jirou Tachibana\n
Still a detective. I didn't know he was at Satsukigaoka Police Station.

column5:
大瀧　剛　（おおたき　つよし）\n
さつきヶ丘警察の署長さん。\n
今日だけは、ボクが一日署長だけど
column6:
Tsuyoshi Ohtaki\n
Chief of the Satsukigaoka Police. Just for today, _I'm_ the chief of police, though.

column5:
『獣』　（けもの）\n
喫茶店のマスター‥だと思ってたら
実は情報屋。ちょっとビックリ。
column6:
{Beast}\n
The owner of a coffee shop...or so I thought, but he's actually an information vendor. Bit of a surprise.

どこに行きます？
column6: Where are we going?

column5: 外に出ますか？
column6: Are you leaving?

Leave\n

column5:
何か用ですかね？\n
私は、警察に捕まる様な事はしてま
せんよ。
column6: Do you want something from me? I've done nothing to get arrested by the police.

column5:
いい絵だと思いませんか。\n
無名の画家の、無名な絵ですがね‥
妙に惹かれるんですよ。
column6: Don't think it's a very good painting, do you? It's a nameless picture by a nameless artist...I'm strangely charmed by it.

column5: ‥そんな大層なモンかなぁ。
column6: ...Is it really so great?

column5:
なんかよく分かんないけど、
がんばってね〜。
column6: I don't really know what this is about, but[nbsp]-- good luck.
column7: NOTE: and yet again, this is almost but not quite a dupe of 3861 and 4288! how many times did they make completely meaningless changes to this line, then forget to update the other copies??

column5:
送会話するだけで、コンピュータを
使う事が出来るようになるんです。
column7: NOTE: misdetected, though it is part of a valid (but unused in this block) script

column5:
あれ、ナビも売られてるじゃ
ない。
column6: Oh, they're selling you too, Navi.

column5: ナビはナビだけですって。
column6: Come on, Navi is _only_ Navi.

column5:
商品名はＯＲＵＫＡだって、
言ったじゃないですか！
column6: Haven't I _told_ you that the product's name is Oruka!?

column5:
高い割にはＯＲＵＫＡも、そ
こそこ売れてるみたいですね。
column6: It seems like Oruka is selling at a fairly good rate.

column5:
街でＯＲＵＫＡをしている人
を、たまに見かけますもの。
column6: I see people in the city wearing it from time to time.

column5:
メイ！まさか、お金を盗むつ
もりじゃないでしょうね。
column6: May! You're not thinking of stealing the money, are you!?

column5:
あ、あのねぇ‥。\n
信用しなさいよ！
column6: Excuse me...Have a little faith in me, will you!?

column5:
まるで森の中でテレビを見て
る気分ですよね。
column6: It feels just like we're watching TV in a forest.

column5:
小さな店ですけど、在庫は豊
富みたいですねぇ。
column6: It's a small shop, but they have plentiful stock.

column5: 電話機も売ってるんですね。
column6: So they sell telephones, too.

column5:
ボクも留守番電話、買おうか
な‥。
column6: Maybe I should buy an answerphone...

column5:
ムダ遣いはやめましょうよ。
どうせ電話してくれる人もいないん
ですから。
column6: Don't waste your money. It's not like there's anyone who'd call you anyway.

column5:
ＭＥＣ製のモニタ一体型パソ
コンですね。
column6: It's a monitor-body PC made by MEC.

column5:
拡張性には乏しいですけど、
お値段が手ごろなんですよ。
column6: Though lacking in terms of extensibility, it's modestly priced.

column5:
ナビ。いつからセールスを始
めるようになったの？
column6: Navi...Since when are you a salesperson?

　　　　　　　　　　　仁科

column5:
素子‥食べてばかりいると、
太るよ。
column6: Motoko...If you do nothing but eat, you're going to get fat.

column5:
大きなお世話！\n
私は太らないタチだから、大丈夫な
のよ。
column6:
Oh, buzz off!\n
I'm the type that doesn't gain weight, so it's fine.

column5:
ありがとう、かんな。\n
おかげで重要な手がかりが見つかっ
たよ。
column6:
Thank you, Kanna.\n
We found a major clue thanks to you.

column5: よかった‥。
column6: Wonderful...

column5:
それがねぇ‥、気になる事が
あったのよ。
column6: So, hey...There's something that's been bothering me.

column5:
お隣さんの部屋が、ずいぶん
騒がしくってね。
column6: My neighbor's room was really noisy, right?

column5:
何かあったのかと思って外に
出てみたら、知らない男が出てきた
のよ。
column6: So I went outside thinking something was going on, and this guy I didn't know came out.

column5:
自分は刑事だって言ってたけ
ど‥、な〜んか、うさんくさい刑事
だったわねぇ。
column6: He said he was a police detective, but he was...like, a really suspicious detective.

column5: 他には、何もなかったわよ。
column6: Nothing else happened.

column5:
警察の手帳は見せてくれたし
態度も丁寧だったけどねえ‥。
column6: He showed me his police ID and he was perfectly polite and all, but...

column5:
何て言うのかな、すごく冷た
い感じがしたのよねぇ。
column6: Like, how do I put it...He gave off this really cold feeling, you know?

column5:
誰だろ？\n
ボクが知ってる警察関係者といった
ら‥。
column6:
Who could that be?\n
If we consider people I know who're connected to the police...

column5:
大瀧署長　　　　立花刑事\n
榊　　　　　　　分からない
column6:
Chief Ohtaki
[sp]<$70>
Detective Tachibana
\n

Sakaki
[sp]<$70>
Don't know

column5: この人じゃなかったわねぇ。
column6: Well, it wasn't him.

column5:
見る\n
立ち去る
column6:
Look\n
Leave

column5:
ファイル　　　　大きい封筒\n
見ない
column6:
Files
[sp]<$70>
Large Envelope
\n

Don't look

column5: そうそうそう!!この男よ！
column6: Yeah, yeah, YEAH! This guy!

column5:
さ、榊が?!\n
う〜、最悪の展開かも‥。
column6:
S-Sakaki!?\n
Ooh, this may be the worst-case scenario...

column5:
刑事さんなら、事情次第で人
の家に入っても構わないかもしれな
いけどねぇ‥。
column6: I mean, I guess depending on the circumstances, there are times where it's okay for a detective to go in somebody's house, but...

column5:
ほんとに刑事だったのかな、
って思うのよ。
column6: I just wonder if he was really a detective.

column5:
ファイルというファイルが、
全てぶちまけられてます。\n
なんか、もうムチャクチャですね。
column6: Every last file's been strewn across the floor. It seems to be in total disarray.

column5:
きれいに整頓されていたのに
見る影もありませんね。
column6: Not a trace remains of its former tidiness.

column5:
引出しもこじ開けられてます
でも‥気になるような物はありませ
んね。
column6: The drawers have all been wrenched open. But...there's nothing here that really stands out.

column5:
葉ちゃんの部屋まで‥何も見
つからないと思うんですけどねぇ。
column6: Even Yoh's room...Though I doubt they found anything here.

column5:
ベッドを切り裂いてまで調べ
てるよ?!
column6: They even went as far as tearing up the bed!?

column5:
手際がいいというか‥徹底的
ですよね。
column6: What a skillful job...They're certainly thorough.

column5: 葉ちゃんのベッドまで‥‥。
column6: Yoh's bed, too...

column5:
ああぁぁ‥葉、悲しむだろう
なぁ‥。
column6: Aaaah...Yoh will be so sad...

column5:
キッチンもムチャクチャです
ねぇ。
column6: The kitchen's a mess, too.

column5:
冷蔵庫まで物色してる‥。\n
お腹でも空いてたのかなぁ。
column6: They've even raided the refrigerator. Maybe they were hungry?

column5:
‥冗談を言ってる場合じゃな
いと思いますが。
column6: ...I don't think this is any time to be making jokes.

column5:
冗談でも言ってないと、やっ
てられないよ。
column6: I won't be able to go on if I can't even make jokes.

column5:
暗証番号が分からなかったん
でしょうか。\n
金庫は無事だったみたいですよ。
column6: Did they not know the code number? It looks like the safe is...safe.
column7:
NOTE: there's no pun here in japanese, but this is one of those situations where you really can't avoid making one in english.

also, it would have been clever here if they'd made it so sakaki would raid the safe if you left the jigsaw puzzle with the clue on it completed in the previous segment, but would fail otherwise. ah well.

column5:
友美さんも葉ちゃんも、姿が
見えませんね。
column6: I don't see Tomomi or Yoh around.

column5: 出かけたのかな？
column6: Did they go out?

column5:
友美さんも葉ちゃんも、姿が
見えませんね。
column6: I don't see Tomomi or Yoh around.

column5:
あのねっ！\n
落ち着いてる場合じゃないよっ！
column6: Hey, this is no time to be calm!

column5:
とにかく、何か手がかりがな
いか探してみないと‥。
column6: Right now, we need to try to find if there's some kind of clue...

column5: 変わった点はないみたいです
column6: Nothing seems to be out of place here.

column5:
え？\n
もう着替えたんですか。\n
式典まで、まだ時間がありますよ。
column6:
Huh?\n
You've already changed? It's still a while before the parade.

column5:
園木の事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:

Leave

column5: 留守みたいですね。
column6: It looks like no one's home.

column5:
園木の事を聞く\n
刑事の事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask about Sonoki\n
Ask about the detective\n
Leave

column5: 友美さんって‥文学派だね。
column6: So Tomomi is the literary type, huh?

column5:
メイも読んでみるべきだと思
いますけどね。
column6: I really think you should try reading too, May.

column5: ポットのお湯が沸いてますね
column6: The water in the pot has been heated.

column5: な、何か分かったの？
column6: H-have you figured something out?

column5: いいえ、それだけですけど。
column6: No, that's all.

column5:
わあぁ！\n
メイお姉ちゃん、かっこいいぃ！
column6:
WHOA!\n
Miss May, you're soooo cool!

column5:
葉ね、ちゃんと友美お姉ちゃん
と一緒に待ってるよ。
column6: Yoh is waiting with Miss Tomomi like a good girl, see?

column5:
お求めの品がございまし
たらぁ、お申しつけ下さいね。\n
それでは、ごゆっくりぃ。
column6: If there is anything you neeed, please do aaask. Well, take it eeeasy.

[2x]\s<$01>ああぁもう?!\n
\n

There's not a clue ANYWHERE!

column5:
あ、あら‥メイさん。\n
どうかされたんですか？
column6:
O-oh, my...May.\n
Whatever is the matter?

column5: ‥何かあったんでしょうか？
column6: ...Has something happened?

column5: いえ‥、私は知りません。
column6: No...I don't know about him.

column5: ‥あら、あなた。
column6: ...Oh, it's you.

column5:
友美さん?!\n
よ、よかった〜。\n
無事だったんだぁ‥‥。
column6:
Tomomi!?\n
Thank goodness! You're safe...

column5:
無事って、ちょっとお買物に
行ってきただけなんですけど‥。
column6: `Safe~...? We just stepped out for a bit to go shopping...

column5:
あ、そうそう。アップルパイ
買ってきたんです。\n
よかったら、メイさんもどうぞ。
column6: Oh, that's right! We bought apple pie. You're welcome to some if you'd like.

column5:
‥‥‥‥‥そんな！\n
園木さんの部屋が?!
column6:
...No!\n
Mr. Sonoki's room was...!?

column5: はいは〜い‥。
column6: Coming, comiiing...

column5:
そう！\n
幸い無事だったから良かったけど‥
column6:
Yes!\n
Luckily, you were safe, but...

column5:
しばらくは外に出ないように
したほうがいいね。
column6: I think it'd be best if you avoided going outside for now.

column5:
アップルパイを食べる\n
どこに出かけたのかを聞く
column6:
Eat the apple pie\n
Ask where they went

column5:
２丁目のサンダンスっていう
お店で買ってきたんです。
column6: We went to get that at a cafe in District 2 called Sun Dance.

column5:
目立たないお店ですけどアッ
プルパイが美味しいって評判なんで
すよ。
column6: It's not a place that stands out much, but it has a reputation for delicious apple pie.

column5:
そのお店にね、\n
パパのお友だちの人がいたの。
column6: Papa's friend was at that cafe.

column5:
でも、葉はよく知らないから、
お話しなかったけど。
column6: But Yoh doesn't really know him, so she didn't talk to him.

column5:
サンダンスというお店に行っ
てきたんです。
column6: We went to a cafe called Sun Dance.

column5:
２丁目にあるんですけどアッ
プルパイが美味しいって評判で‥。
column6: It's in District 2, and they have a reputation for delicious apple pie, so...

column5:
葉ちゃんが食べたいって言う
から買ってきたんですよ。
column6: Since Yoh said she was hungry, we bought some.

column5:
そのお店にね、\n
パパのお友だちの人がいたの。
column6: Papa's friend was at that cafe.

column5:
でも、葉はよく知らないから、
お話しなかったけど。
column6: But Yoh doesn't really know him, so she didn't talk to him.

column5:
パパのお友だちのことを聞く\n
アップルパイの評判を聞く
column6:
Ask about Papa's friend\n
Ask about the apple pie's reputation

column5:
留守かな？\n
ま、こんな騒ぎじゃ、部屋にいる訳
ないか。
column6:
Nobody's home?\n
Well, I guess no one would be in their room in this uproar.

column5: 美味しいでしょう？
column6: Delicious, isn't it?

column5:
ご主人はちょっと変わってい
るし、お店も小さいけど‥アップル
パイは、ここが一番ですわ。
column6: The owner is a bit strange, and it's a small cafe...but it's the best place for apple pie.

column5:
葉は知らない人なんだけどね、
１カ月くらい前から、おうちに来る
ようになったの。
column6: Yoh doesn't know him, but he started coming to our house about a month ago.

column5:
お仕事の話をしてるんだって、
パパは言ってた。\n
名前はねぇ‥た、たか、たち？
column6: Papa said they were talking about work. His name was, um...Ta...Taka...Tachi...?

column5:
たちき　　　　　たなばた\n
はなだ　　　　　たちばな\n
たちがれ　　　　たちやま
column6:
Tachiki
[sp]<$70>
Tanabata
\n

Hanada
[sp]<$70>
Tachibana
\n

Tachigare
[sp]<$70>
Tachiyama

column5:
ううん‥違うの。\n
もう少しで思い出せそうなんだけど
なぁ‥‥。
column6:
No...not that.\n
I think I'll remember if I think a bit more...

column5:
変装もムダになっちゃいまし
たね‥。\n
普段着に着替えます？
column6: Guess the disguise ended up being useless...Are you going to change back to your normal clothes?

column5:
ううん。\n
この格好も気に入っちゃったからね
column6:
Nah.\n
I've taken a shine to this look, too.

column5: 何になさいます？
column6: What would you like?

column5:
メ〜イ〜。何しようとしてる
んです？
column6: Maaay. What do you think you're doing?

column5:
違う、違うの！葉、思いだした
たちばなって言う人だったよ。
column6: No, no! Yoh remembers now. It was a man called Tachibana.

column5:
そうそうそう！\n
メイお姉ちゃん、よく分かったねぇ
column6:
Yeah, yeah, yeah!\n
That's right, Miss May.

column5:
たちばな‥って、もしかして
こんな人？
column6: Tachibana...Was it maybe a guy like this?

column5:
うん、この人！\n
この人がね、お店のおじさんとお話
していたの。
column6:
Yeah, that guy!\n
He was talking to the man that runs the cafe.

column5:
葉ちゃんの言ってた‥その、
立花さんですけど。
column6: This Mr., um...Tachibana that Yoh was talking about...

column5:
サンダンスのご主人と話して
らしたのですが‥何か、こう‥表情
が深刻な印象がしたんです。
column6: He was talking to Sun Dance's owner, but...somehow, well...I got the feeling he had a grave expression.

column5:
思い過ごしかもしれませんけ
ど、何となく気になりまして‥。
column6: Perhaps I'm overthinking it, but for some reason, it's bothering me...

column5:
今日の式典にメイさんが出席
されるんですよね？\n
がんばってくださいね。
column6: You'll be appearing in the parade today, won't you? Good luck!

column5:
テレビで放送されるそうです
から、私も拝見させて頂きますわ。
column6: I heard it's going to be broadcast on TV, so I'll be watching you too.

column5:
４丁目で事件があったそ
うですね。\n
自殺だったそうですが。
column6: I heard there was an incident in District 4. Apparently, it was a suicide.

column5:
式典は予定通り行われま
すから、問題はありませんけど。
column6: But the parade will be going ahead as scheduled, so it's no problem.

column5:
事件の事を話す\n
廃ビルの事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Talk about the case\n
Ask about the abandoned building\n
Leave

column5:
立花？‥‥知らんな。\n
いちいち客の名前を覚えているわけ
もないからな。
column6:
Tachibana?...Dunno.\n
You think I remember the name of every customer that walks in?

column5:
２年前だったかな？\n
ぼくは学生だったんですけどね。
column6:
Two years ago, was it?\n
I was a student, anyway.

column5:
その‥『オカルト研究会』っ
てのに入ってましてね。
column6: So...I'd joined this Occult Research Society, right?

column5:
幽霊の写真を撮るんだって、
メンバーと一緒に、１丁目にある廃
ビルの地下に忍び込んだんですよ。
column6: We were talking about taking pictures of ghosts, so the members and I snuck into the basement of the abandoned building in District 1.

column5:
まあ結局、何台かの車がほこ
りをかぶってただけで、何もなかっ
たんですけど。
column6: But, well, in the end, there was nothing there but some cars caked in dust.

column5:
写真だけ撮って外に出てから
が悲惨だったんですよ。
column6: Tragically, all I did was take a photo and leave.

column5:
運悪く、巡回中の警官に見つ
かって‥、アヤシイ奴らって事で捕
まっちゃいました。
column6: Then we had the bad luck to get found by a police officer making the rounds...We got arrested for being a `suspicious bunch.~

column5:
後で調べたら、５年前にビル
が放棄されるまで、向かいの警察が
駐車場を利用してたそうでして。
column6: When I looked into it later, I heard the police across the way used it for parking until the building was abandoned five years before.

column5:
それもあって、よけいアヤシ
イと思われたんでしょうかねぇ。
column6: Considering that, we just looked all the more suspicious, huh?

column5:
今の時間は、アップルパ
イとコーヒーだけだ。\n
それでいいかね。
column6: We've got nothing but apple pie and coffee this time of day. That fine?

column5:
アップルパイを注文する\n
注文しない
column6:
Order apple pie\n
Don't order

column5: 無愛想なマスターだなぁ‥。
column6: What an unfriendly host...

column5:
あらま、これ‥すっごく美味
しいよ！
column6: Oh, gee...This is REALLY delicious!

column5: なんか悔しい‥。
column6: Somehow, I'm a bit peeved...

column5:
一人一日一個ずつ。\n
これが、この店のきまりだ。
column6:
One per customer per day.\n
That's the rule at this cafe.

column5:
美味しかったのに‥。\n
へ、変な店。
column6:
Even though it was so good...?\n
Wh-what a weird cafe.

column5:
何かあったんですか？沢
田さんが、ずいぶん慌てていました
けど。
column6:
Did something happen?\n
Sawada was in quite the rush.
column7: NOTE: near-dupe of 4385 with no manual linebreak on first line

column5:
あ、ごめんなさい。\n
すぐに出ますから‥。
column6: Oh, I'm sorry. I'll be leaving soon...

column5:
おい！\n
それ以上、中に入るんじゃない。
column6:
Hey!\n
You're not going any further than that.

column5: さて、接続したよ。
column6: All right, it's connected.

column5:
パソコンを起動する\n
動作原理を聞く\n
ナビをはずす
column6:
Boot the PC\n
Hear the operating principles\n
Disconnect Navi

column5:
ナビのホログラム機能を利用
してるんです。
column6: Navi is making use of her hologram feature.

column5:
ホログラムのレーザー光で、
光ケーブルを通して信号をパソコン
に送って、操作してるんですよ。
column6: Using the hologram's laser beam, I'm sending signals to and controlling the PC through the optical cable.

column5:
事件の事を聞く　立花の事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Ask about incident
[sp]<$70>
Ask about Tachibana
\n

Leave

column5:
事件の事を聞く　立花の事を聞く\n
偽名の事を話す　立ち去る
column6:
Ask about incident
[sp]<$70>
Ask about Tachibana
\n

Tell about alias
[sp]<$70>
Leave

column5:
遺書等は見つかってませんけ
どね。
column6: We haven't found any kind of suicide note.

column5:
現場の状況から、木下氏は自
殺と判断されましたよ。
column6: Based on the state of the crime scene, Mr. Kinoshita's death has been ruled a suicide.

column5:
今日は、ずいぶんイライラし
てましたね。
column6: He's been really on edge today, hasn't he?

column5:
娘さんを亡くしたのが、さす
がにショックだったんでしょう‥。
column6: I suppose losing his daughter must have been a shock...

column5: 『木下』が偽名？
column6: `Kinoshita~ is an alias?

column5:
そんなはずはありませんよ。
署の方から、身元が確認されたと連
絡がありましたから。
column6: That can't be. We got word from the station that his identity had been confirmed.

column5: 洗いものが残ってますね。
column6: The dirty dishes have been left out.

column5:
洗いものが残ってますね。\n
‥‥‥メイ、どうしたんです？
column6: The dirty dishes have been left out. ...May, what's the matter?

column5: 気にかかるんだよね。
column6: There's something bothering me.

column5:
部屋を、あれほどきちんと整
頓しているきちょうめんな人がだよ\n
洗いものを残して自殺する？
column6: This was a methodical man who kept his room neatly organized, as we saw...Would he have left the dishes out and killed himself?

column5:
きちんと整頓されてるねぇ。
きちょうめんな性格の人だったみた
い。
column6:
It's all neatly organized.\n
He seems to have had a very meticulous personality.

column5:
荒された形跡がないわけです
から、これも自殺だと判断された理
由の１つでしょう。
column6: There's no sign of a break-in, which is probably one of the reasons it's been ruled a suicide.

column5:
このロープは？\n
何でベッドに縛りつけられてるの？
column6:
What's this rope?\n
Why's it tied to the bed?

column5:
ああ、それで首を吊っていた
んですよ。
column6: Oh, he hung himself with that.

column5:
高さがなくてもできるそうで
すからね。\n
メイ、マネしないでくださいよ。
column6: It sounds like you can pull it off even without much height. May, don't imitate him.

column5: するわけないでしょ！
column6: As if I'd do _THAT_!

column5:
ベッドに縛りつけたロープで
首を吊ったんですね。
column6: So he hanged himself with the rope tied to the bed.
column7: NOTE: unlike the police officer, navi would of course properly use "hanged" rather than "hung", no matter how stiff it sounds

column5:
ある程度の高さで十分なんだ
そうです。
column6: It sounds like that height was sufficient for it.

column5:
医学、薬学、解剖学、医化学
‥難解な専門書ばかりです。
column6: Medicine, pharmaceutics, anatomy, medical chemistry...It's full of esoteric, difficult-to-understand books.

column5:
元医師だったんだもの。\n
当然だよ。
column6:
He _was_ a former doctor.\n
It's only natural.

column5: 雑誌と‥メモがあります。
column6: There's a magazine, and...a note.

column5:
雑誌を見る\n
メモを見る\n
立ち去る
column6:
Look at the magazine\n
Look at note\n
Leave

column5:
車の雑誌ですね。\n
亡くなった窪田さんの趣味だったん
でしょうか？
column6: It's a car magazine. Was that the deceased Kubota's hobby?

column5:
机の本棚にも、同じ雑誌が、
ずいぶん並んでます。
column6: There are many more of the same magazine on the desk's bookshelf.

column5:
五月星は、太陽の前に黙して座り\n
続ける。\n
欲しいものは『ケモノ』
column6:
The fifth month's star remains sitting silently before the sun.\n
What it seeks is the {beast.}
column7: NOTE: here, the name for the month of may is written as it would normally be in Japanese -- "go-gatsu", literally "the fifth month". may then make the connection that this is a coded reference to her name. obviously, this has to be adjusted a bit to work in english.

column5:
ああ、それは立花刑事が残し
ていったものなんですけどね。
column6: Ahh, that's something Detective Tachibana left.

column5:
触るなとか言って出て行かれ
ましたけど‥。\n
あの人も何を考えているのかなぁ。
column6: He kept saying not to touch it as he went out...Wonder what he's thinking.

column5:
五月星だって、英訳すればメ
イ・スターだよ。\n
‥ふざけてるなぁ。
column6:
`The fifth month's star~...That would be a `May star.'\n
...Having a laugh, is he?

column5:
つまり、これはメイへの伝言
だって事ですよね。
column6: So, that means this is a message to you, May.

column5:
壁に写真が貼ってありますよ
全部で５枚ですけど、車の写真ばか
りですね。
column6: There are pictures stuck on the wall. There are five in total, but they're all photos of cars.

column5:
Ｎａｔｕｒｅ　　Ｔｒｕｔｈ\n
ＲＥＮｙ　　　　Ｓ’ｅｎｃｅ\n
ｓｏＬｖｅ　　　立ち去る
column6:
Nature
[sp]<$70>
Truth
\n

RENy
[sp]<$70>
S'ence
\n

soLve
[sp]<$70>
Leave

column5:
『Ｎａｔｕｒｅ』ですね。\n
最近、発表されたばかりの車ですよ
column6:
That's `Nature.~\n
It's a car that was only just recently released.

column5:
確か街頭ＴＶでも宣伝してま
した。
column6: As I recall, they were advertising it on the street TV.

column5:
『Ｔｒｕｔｈ』ですか。\n
６年ぐらい前の車だと思いましたけ
ど。
column6:
Is this `Truth~?\n
I think it's a car from around six years ago.

column5:
『ＲＥＮｙ』です。\n
２年前のモデルですね。
column6:
It's `RENy.~\n
That's a two-year-old model.

column5:
『Ｓ’ｅｎｃｅ』‥エッセン
スって読むんですよ。
column6: `S'ence~...You say that as `essence.~

column5:
５年前に発表されて、ずいぶ
ん人気があったらしいですね。
column6: It was released five years ago, and I've heard it was really popular.

column5: 『ｓｏＬｖｅ』？
column6: `soLve~?

column5:
かなり古いタイプなんでしょ
うか‥ナビのデータには記録されて
ませんねぇ。
column6: Maybe it's an older type...It's not recorded in Navi's data.

column5:
おかえりなさい、沢田さん。
ボクの為に迷惑をかけてしまって‥
ごめんなさい。
column6:
Welcome back, Sawada.\n
I've caused you a lot of trouble over this...Sorry.

column5:
気にするな。\n
それより、状況はどうなんだ？
column6:
Don't worry about it.\n
Anyway, what's the situation?

column5: 状況はどうだ？
column6: What's going on?

column5:
事件の事を話す\n
局での調査結果を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Talk about the case\n
Ask about the station investigation\n
Leave

column5:
‥そうか、捜査は進んでいる
ようだな。\n
たいしたもんだよ。
column6: ...Well, sounds like you're making progress. Good to hear.

column5:
しかし、式典まであまり時間
がないんだぞ。\n
遅刻して困らせないでくれよ。
column6: But there's not much time left till the parade. Don't screw things up by being late.

column5:
『本物の検案書』？\n
ふぅむ‥、どこかに隠してあると考
えるのが自然だろうがなぁ‥‥。
column6: The real autopsy report? Hmm...I guess you'd figure it's got to be hidden somewhere...

column5:
お前の親父さんな。うちの局
と協力して『組織』の捜査を進めて
いたんだ。
column6: Right, your dad[nbsp]-- he worked with our station to move his investigation into the Syndicate forward.

column5:
だから、亡くなった時にあれ
だけ大きく報道されたんだが‥。
column6: So, when he passed, it was covered pretty extensively.

column5:
それでだ。その捜査に協力し
ていた奴に聞いたんだが‥。
column6: I talked to a guy who worked with the investigation...

column5:
草薙氏は睡眠薬なんぞを使用
するほど、やわな人間じゃなかった
だと。
column6: He said Mr. Kusanagi wasn't a weak man who'd man go using stuff like sleeping medicine.

column5:
気力も充実していたし、睡眠
薬で自殺したとの警察の発表には、
納得できない‥そう言っていた。
column6: He told me he was full of energy, and that he couldn't accept the police statement that he killed himself with sleeping pills.

column5:
草薙氏が自殺する理由もなけ
れば、睡眠薬を所持している理由も
ない。
column6: There was no reason for Mr. Kusanagi to kill himself, and no reason for him to have sleeping pills.

column5:
だから、警察の発表には納得
がいかない。\n
彼に協力していた奴の言葉だ。
column6: So, the police statement isn't convincing. That's what a guy who worked with him said.

column5: 何か進展しましたか？
column6: Any new developments?

column5:
ぼくにも、協力できる事があ
ればいいんですけど‥。
column6: I'd like to do what I can to help too, but...

column5:
式典が始まるまで、そん
なに時間はありませんよ。
column6: There's not much time until the parade starts.

column5:
あまり遠くへ行かないよ
うにお願いします。
column6: Please don't go too far off.

column5: 何を知りたい？
column6: What do you want to know?

column5: ご注文は？
column6: What'll it be?

column5:
ふん、少しばかり時間はかかっ
たが‥。立花の親父の言うとおり、
まるきりのバカではなさそうだな。
column6: Hmph. Took you a bit, but...Just like ol' man Tachibana said, seems you're not a complete idiot.

column5:
おれが『獣』だ。\n
聞きたいことがあるんだろう？
column6:
I'm `Beast.~\n
Got something you want to ask?

column5:
悪いが売り切れだ。\n
また明日にでも来てくれ。
column6:
Sorry, we're sold out.\n
Come back tomorrow.

column5:
あいにくだが、うちには
置いてねぇ。\n
他をあたってくれ。
column6: Hate to tell you, but we don't got that. Have something else.

column5:
注文しねぇんなら、出て
行ってくれ。
column6: If you ain't buyin', get out of here.

column5:
『獣』と話す\n
事件の事を聞く\n
立ち去る
column6:
Talk to Beast\n
Ask about the case\n
Leave
